questions.text: The fasting blood glucose levels of a  population from two overlapping distributions are shown in the below graph. A test was done with the cutoff of 120mg/ dl for diagnosing diabetes. What does the shaded area represent?
questions.solution:
The shaded area represents the false positives (Non-diabetics incorrectly classified as diabetics). 

Related Pearl: Cut-off points in diagnostic tests

  • Highly sensitive test, when negative, rules out a disease. (Screening test)
  • Highly specific test, when positive, rules in a disease. (Confirmatory test)

Sensitivity (True-positive rate): High sensitivity indicates low false-negative rate.

Specificity (True-negative rate): High specificity indicates low false-positive rate.

questions.text: In a suspected case of rheumatoid arthritis, which of the following markers should be used to diagnose this condition?
questions.solution:
The most appropriate marker to diagnose rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is the anti-CCP (cyclic citrullinated peptide) antibody as it is the most specific marker for RA.

Anti-CCP, ESR, and CRP values correlate with the disease activity.

Rheumatoid factor can occur in other autoimmune diseases as well as in chronic infections. Therefore it is not considered specific.

questions.text: A multiparous woman presented with a urethrocele, due to weakness of the urogenital diaphragm. What is this structure also known as?
questions.solution:
The urogenital diaphragm is also known as the triangular ligament. 

The urogenital diaphragm extends from the pubic arch anteriorly to the central point of the perineum posteriorly and consists of two layers of fascia through which pass the vagina and the urethra. The central point of the female perineum lies between the vagina and the rectum.

Urogenital triangle:

  • Present between 2 ischiopubic rami
  • Stretching transversely across the rami there are 3 membranes.
  • From above downwards the membranes are as follows:
    • Superior fascia of urogenital diaphragm
    • Inferior fascia of urogenital diaphragm
    • Membranous layer of superficial perineal fascia

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman with suspected diazepam overdose was administered the antidote for benzodiazepine poisoning. Which of the following statements is false about this antidote?

choices.text: It is a specific antagonist of benzodiazepines
It may be used to treat barbiturate poisoning
It acts at the same site on GABA channel where benzodiazepines bind

questions.solution:
Flumazenil is the antidote used in benzodiazepine poisoning. It is not used to treat barbiturate poisoning. 

Flumazenil is a benzodiazepine (BZD) receptor-specific antagonist. It has no affinity for barbiturate binding sites on the GABA receptor Cl- channel complex. Flumazenil competes with BZD agonists and inverse agonists for the BZD receptors. 

Flumazenil is available only for intravenous use. It is used to treat benzodiazepine overdose and for the reversal of sedative effects produced by benzodiazepines administered during general anesthesia.

questions.text: A newborn presented to the NICU with respiratory distress and meconium discharge from the umbilicus. The condition occurs due to the patency of the duct that connects the primitive gut to the ____________.
questions.solution:
The presence of meconium discharge at the umbilicus is suggestive of vitelline fistula. It occurs due to patent vitelline duct, which connects the primitive gut to the yolk sac.

The primitive gut is connected to the definitive yolk sac through a narrow stalk-like communication known as the vitellointestinal duct. It is also known as vitelline duct or yolk stalk or omphalomesenteric duct. 

Due to the folding of the embryo in the cephalocaudal and lateral directions, the embryo gets enclosed all around by ectoderm, except in the region through which the vitellointestinal duct passes. In this region, there is a circular aperture, which is now called the umbilical opening. The vitellointestinal duct completely obliterates by the 7th week of development.

Vitelline duct abnormalities:

  • Meckel's diverticulum: In about 2% o the individuals, a portion of the vitelline duct persists an outpouching of the ileum called, Meckel diverticulum. The diverticulum is usually asymptomatic unless it contains heterotopic pancreatic or gastric mucosa, which may lead to bleeding, ulceration, or perforation.
  • Vitelline cyst: In some individuals, both the ends of the vitelline duct transforms into fibrous cords. However, the middle portion of the duct forms a large cyst called, enterocystoma, or vitelline cyst. As the fibrous cords run across the peritoneal cavity, it may lead to intestinal obstruction, strangulation, or volvulus.

questions.text: A 10-month-old male baby is brought with vomiting, lethargy, and severe jaundice when weaning was started with fruit juice. Which of the following enzymes is most likely defective?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of hereditary fructose intolerance (HFI), which is due to deficiency of the enzyme aldolase B.

Individuals affected with HFI are asymptomatic until they ingest fructose or sucrose (usually in the form of fruit, fruit juice, or sweetened cereal). Symptoms include:

  • Hepatomegaly
  • Jaundice
  • Vomiting
  • Lethargy
  • Convulsions
  • Hypoglycemia

Urine-reducing sugar (Benedict's test) and tests for ketoses (Rapid Furfural and Seliwanoff's test) are positive. Treatment is the removal of fructose and sucrose from the diet.

The flowchart given below depicts fructose metabolism. 

Other options: 

Option A: A deficiency of aldolase A leads to myopathy and hemolytic anemia.

Option C: Fructokinase deficiency leads to essential fructosuria, which is a benign condition and does not have significant clinical manifestations. 

Option D: Hexokinase deficiency is a rare mutation that can present with hemolytic anemia and does not present with the symptoms in this patient.

questions.text: A farmer presents with blurring of vision in his left eye. He has a history of injury with a bush to the same eye while working. An ulcer is seen in his cornea with feathery margins. Slit-lamp examination shows infiltrates in the corneal stroma in a circular fashion. Which type of hypersensitivity reaction causes these infiltrates?
questions.solution:
The given clinical situation points towards a fungal corneal ulcer and the infiltrates of stroma in a circular fashion are suggestive of the immune ring of Wessely. This immune ring is due to type 3 hypersensitivity reaction (antigen-antibody complex).

The immune ring of Wessely can be made out as a deep stromal haze in a slit lamp. It occurs as a result of the deposition of antigen-antibody complexes in the stroma. Once deposited it draws the immune cells, inciting further inflammation.

The given shows an ulcer in the cornea and the adjacent immune ring of Wessely.

questions.text: In which of the following ways does aldosterone react with renal tubular cells?

choices.text: Increases transport of ENaCs from the cytoplasm to the cell membrane
Binds to steroid receptor inside the nucleus of renal tubular cells
Binds to ENaC's on the cell membrane and increase Na+ transport
Binds to G-protien coupled receptors on the cell surface

questions.solution:
Aldosterone increases transport of ENaCs (epithelial sodium channels) from the cytoplasm to the cell membrane. This is a rapid effect of aldosterone. 

Mechanism of action of aldosterone:

  • Aldosterone diffuses into the renal tubular epithelial cells and combines with a miner­alocorticoid receptor (MR) in the cytoplasm.
  • The aldosterone-receptor complex diffuses into the nucleus and induces transcription. 
  • The mRNA diffuses back into the cytoplasm and undergoes translation to form proteins. These have two effects - Rapid and Slow.
  • The slower effect is increase in synthesis of ENaCs.
  • The important products formed are:
    • Na+K+ATPase 
    • membrane transport proteins like epithelial sodium channel

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the clinic with pain over the lateral aspect of her right breast for the past 5 days. Examination finding is as shown in the image. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Mondor's disease. The image shows the presence of a subcutaneous cord and a narrow shallow groove along the side of the cord.

Mondor’s disease is the thrombophlebitis of the superficial veins of the breast and anterior chest wall. The most commonly involved vein is the lateral thoracic vein. Patients usually present with pain along the lateral chest wall and a tender, firm cord below the breast. It is a benign condition and gets resolved on its own within 4-6 weeks. Warm compresses and anti-inflammatory medicines can be used to reduce pain. If the symptoms persist despite medications, the affected segment of the vein can be excised.

Option A: Tietze’s syndrome is a benign inflammation of one or more costal cartilages.

Option B: Zuska disease is the subcutaneous abscess of the breast tissue beneath the areola of the nipple. It is also called a subareolar abscess.

Option D: Stewart–Treves Syndrome is characterized by lymphangiosarcoma in chronic long-standing lymphedema following mastectomy.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with abdominal pain and constipation. A barium enema reveals an apple core sign. In which part of the colon is such a growth commonly seen?
questions.solution:
Apple core sign on barium enema is suggestive of a constricting type of colon cancer that is more common on the left side. Ulcerative type is more common on the right side.

Most patients with left-sided colon cancers often present with increasing constipation while patients with right-sided colon cancer often present with melena and fatigue associated with anemia.

The apple core sign describes a short segment irregular circumferential stricture of the large bowel that has abrupt shouldered margins resembling an apple core.

questions.text: While examining a patient with hair loss, you notice several thin, broken hairs that are thinner towards the scalp and easily pulled out. What is the diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has alopecia areata. The characteristic finding described in this vignette is called exclamation mark hair. 

Alopecia areata is a chronic inflammatory disease that causes non-scarring patches of hair loss. It is a T-cell mediated inflammatory disease that occurs in genetically predisposed patients. 

The lesions of alopecia areata are characterized by a smooth circumscribed patch of alopecia. Exclamation mark hair refers to short extractable broken hairs which are thinner towards the base, as shown in the image below.

questions.text: The husband of an AIDS patient noticed that his wife had become forgetful and confused lately. She complained of dizziness and lack of sleep. Eventually, she started behaving bizarrely, paranoid that everybody is trying to kill her. Yesterday she was found in her room talking to somebody who did not exist in reality. Which of the following drugs is most commonly associated with this side effect?
questions.solution:
The given scenario describes psychiatric or CNS adverse effects, which are commonly seen with efavirenz.

The CNS/ psychiatric adverse effects seen with the use of efavirenz are:

  • Frank psychosis (depression, hallucinations, and/or mania) 
  • Impaired concentration
  • Dysphoria 
  • Dizziness
  • Vivid dreams
  • Insomnia

questions.text: A 25-year-old female patient presented with hirsutism. After further evaluation, a diagnosis of HAIR-AN syndrome was made. Which of the following statements is false regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
HAIR-AN syndrome is not characterized by mild hyperandrogenism but marked hyperandrogenism (HA). It also includes insulin resistance (IR) and acanthosis nigricans (AN).

HAIR-AN syndrome and ovarian hyperthecosis are exaggerated phenotypes of polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS). Women affected by HAIR-AN syndrome often present with symptoms of severe hyperandrogenism (hirsutism, acne) and may occasionally display signs of virilization like clitoromegaly, temporal balding and voice deepening.

Ovarian hyperthecosis is a rare condition characterized by nests of luteinized theca cells distributed throughout the ovarian stroma.

questions.text: An elderly man with bone metastasis is receiving intravenous opioids for pain management. Which of the following drugs can be safely administered to him without a risk of developing respiratory depression?
questions.solution:
Buprenorphine can be safely administered to this patient because of its ceiling effect on respiratory depression.

Ceiling effect is defined as no further increase in the effect of the drug with a further increment in dose, once the ceiling level is reached.

Opioid agonist-antagonist compounds produce respiratory depression (and analgesia) with a ceiling effect which means increasing the dose further does not produce any further respiratory depression and may actually result in increased ventilation (due to the predominance of antagonist actions).

Other drugs that show the ceiling effect are:

  • Butorphanol
  • Nalbuphine
  • Pentazocine.

Respiratory depression with morphine, fentanyl & alfentanyl does not have a ceiling effect because they are pure opioid agonists. As the dose increases, respiratory depression also increases progressing to respiratory arrest.

Related Pearl: Ceiling effect of opioids

Drug Correlation of Respiratory Depression With Dose
Morphine

Increases proportionally with dose (i.e. no ceiling effect)
Buprenorphine

Ceiling effect at 0.15-1.2 mg in adults
Butorphanol

Ceiling effect at 30-60 μg/kg
Nalbuphine

Ceiling effect at 30 mg in adults
Pentazocine 

Ceiling effect suggested

questions.text: You are posted as an intern in casualty when an MLC case is brought by the police with the following appearance. She was declared brought dead. What would you mark as the likely cause of death before sending the patient for postmortem?
questions.solution:
The given image shows frothing from nostrils and no clear signs of facial or conjunctival congestion. It is likely a case of drowning.

Frothing may also be seen in throttling or strangulation, but it might be associated with signs of conjunctival congestion, facial congestion, patterned bruise on neck etc. In the absence of these features, it is unlikely to be caused by strangulation. 

Traumatic asphyxia is unlikely as the face of this patient is all whitened without signs of congestion or any obvious signs of trauma

Related Pearl: Differentiating features between Antemortem amd Postmortem drowning

Cadaveric spasm Present Absent

Lungs are voluminous, bulky, water-logged and over-inflated

Not spread to distant organs because of absence of circulation

questions.text: Which of the following is the best line of treatment in a 3-year-old child presenting with a recent onset of 15-degree accommodative esotropia?
questions.solution:
The best line of treatment in accommodative esotropia is a refractive correction.

Esotropia for distance is corrected by the treatment of hypermetropia: convex glasses

Esotropia for near is corrected by +3DS lens.

Algorithm for the management of accommodative esotropia is as follows:

  • R: Refractive correction: Glasses/Miotics
  • O: Orthoptics/Occlusion: for amblyopia
  • O: Operative correction: for non-accommodative component
  • P: Prism correction: for remaining error

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is posted for a circumcision procedure. He is given a pudendal nerve block before the surgery. Which of the following nerve roots are blocked in this technique?
questions.solution:
Pudendal nerve block involves S2S3S4.

Related Pearl: Important Root Values and Cranial Nerve Nuclei

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of paraneoplastic pemphigus?
questions.solution:
Paraneoplastic pemphigus (PNP) is most commonly associated seen with non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. 

PNP is a fatal autoimmune blistering disease associated with underlying benign or malignant neoplasms. It commonly presents 2-3 years after the development of malignancy, but can sometimes precede it as well. It is associated with multiple antigens including desmoglein, desmoplakin, periplakin.

Other associated diseases include:

  • Chronic lymphocytic leukemia
  • Waldenstrom's disease
  • Castleman disease
  • Spindle cell tumor
  • Thymoma

questions.text: As a part of the iodine deficiency control programme, you advocate the usage of iodized salt in hilly areas. What is this type of prevention an example of?
questions.solution:
The usage of iodized salt in iodine-deficient areas like in hilly regions is an example of primary prevention as it provides specific protection.

Global Iodine Deficiency Disorders Prevention Day is observed every year on 21st October to raise awareness about the fair use of iodine, to highlight the factors that lead to iodine deficiency and its consequences. Iodine deficiency disorders are the world’s most prevalent yet easily preventable disorders.

questions.text: Which of the following postmortem changes is shown in the given image?
questions.solution:
The postmortem change shown above is marbling.

The blood in the vessels is hemolyzed, which stains the vessel walls and the adjacent tissues, giving rise to a marbled appearance. The marbling of the skin becomes prominent about 36–48 hours after death in summer and is distinctly appreciable in the superficial veins of the abdomen, shoulders, chest, and inguinal region.

questions.text: The following instrument is used for all except:
questions.solution:
The image shows a double-ended uterine curette with a sharp and a blunt end. It is not used in uterine length measurement.

Uterine length measurement is done with a uterine sound which is given below.

questions.text: Which of the following is more likely to be susceptible to alkylation with a bifunctional alkylating agent?
questions.solution:
The N7 atom of guanine is particularly susceptible to alkylation with bifunctional alkylating agents. It leads to the formation of a covalent bond with bifunctional alkylating agents and represents the key target in nucleic acids for alkylating agents. Alkylation results in cross-linking/abnormal base pairing of DNA which inhibits DNA replication.

Other sites that can be involved are:

  • N1 and N3 of adenosine 
  • N3 of cytosine 
  • O6 of guanine

questions.text: A patient presented with right-sided hemiparesis that completely resolved in 4-6 hours. What score will you use to determine the risk of a future stroke in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features are suggestive of a transient ischemic attack. The risk of stroke following TIAs is determined by the ABCD2 score.  

CHADS2-VASc score is used to determine the risk of stroke in a patient with atrial fibrillation.

CURB-65 is a scoring system used to predict mortality in patients with community-acquired pneumonia.

APACHE II is a scoring system used to predict ICU mortality.

questions.text: A 14 year old male is brought with the complaints of multiple hyperpigmented papules over the face and other sun exposed areas with persistent erythema. He had history of similar episodes since childhood. Which of the following mechanisms is likely to be defective in this condition?

choices.text: Removal of mismatched base during DNA replication
Removal of oligonucleotides containing damaged bases by endonuclease
Removal of the altered base by base specific glycosylase

questions.solution:
The above given clinical findings is suggestive of xeroderma pigmentosum. Defect in the removal of oligonucleotides containing the damaged bases by endonucleases is seen in xeroderma pigmentosum.

Xeroderma Pigmentosum (XP) is a rare autosomal recessive genetic disorder characterized by defective DNA repair which leads to clinical and cellular hypersensitivity to ultraviolet radiation and other carcinogenic agents.  

Important clinical features are:

Intense cutaneous photosensitivity, xerosis, poikiloderma, actinic keratosis, acute burning under minimal sun exposure, erythemas, hyperpigmented lentiginous macules, and malignant lesions in sun-exposed areas, including basocellular carcinoma, squamous cell carcinoma, and melanoma.  

The final diagnosis of XP can be confirmed by special laboratory tests by examining the DNA damage repair in cells from cultures exposed to ultraviolet radiation. The most common tests are skin biopsy and culture of skin fibroblasts.  

There is no cure for XP. Treatment consists of minimizing exposure to sunlight and regular dermatological care, as well as surgery for recurrent tumors excision. Patients should be followed up every 3 months. Genetic counseling is important in a family that has an affected child and is considering having more children.

questions.text:
Match the following:
  1. Urine bag
  2. Nasogastric tube
  3. Underwater seal bag
  4. Suction cannula
questions.solution:
1-B, 2-C, 3-A, 4-D is the correct option.

Urine bags are used for the collection of urine. They are usually attached to a Foley catheter placed to drain the bladder.

An underwater seal bag is used for the collection of fluid from the thoracic cavity. It acts as a one-way valve. This system allows air to leave the pleural cavity, but it cannot be drawn back in by the negative pressure that is created in the intrathoracic cavity.

Nasogastric tube/Ryle’s tube is used for nasogastric feeding/stomach wash/aspiration.

A metallic suction cannula is used to clear the operative field by suctioning secretions, blood, and fluid.

questions.text: In what condition would you see the gallbladder as shown below?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a strawberry gallbladder. Strawberry gallbladder is seen in cholesterolosis and is associated with cholesterol stones.

Cholesterolosis is characterized by mucosal villous hyperplasia. The interior of the gallbladder resembles a strawberry. The yellow specks are aggregations of cholesterol crystals and cholesterol esters in the lamina propria. This corresponds to the seeds of a strawberry.

Option A: Cholesterol polyposis - Cholecystography or ultrasonography shows negative shadows in a functioning gallbladder, indicating the presence of a well-defined polyp.

Options B and C: Cholecystitis glandularis proliferans/adenomyomatosis - All layers of the gallbladder wall may be thickened, but sometimes, an incomplete septum forms that separate the hyperplastic from the normal layer. Intraparietal "mixed" calculi may be present.

questions.text: The histopathologic findings seen in a resected heart mass is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given histological slide shows abundant spider cells. They are seen in rhabdomyoma.

Microscopically, they are composed of bizarre, markedly enlarged myocytes. Routine histologic processing often artifactually reduces the abundant cytoplasm to thin strands that stretch from the nucleus to the surface membrane. This appearance is referred to as “spider” cells.

Rhabdomyoma is the most frequent primary tumour of the pediatric heart. 50% of cases are associated with tuberous sclerosis, with mutations in the tumour-suppressor genes TSC1 and TSC2. They are usually multiple and occur in ventricles preferentially. They often regress spontaneously and may, therefore, be considered as hamartomas.

Image given shows spider cell in rhabdomyoma:

questions.text: In controlled tipping, the amount of land required for the trench method to be practiced for a population of 10,000 is:
questions.solution:
In controlled tipping, one acre of land is required by the trench method to be practiced for a population of 10,000.

It is also known as a sanitary landfill. It is the most satisfactory method of refuse disposal where suitable land is available. In this method, waste material is placed in a trench or other prepared area. Then, it is adequately compacted and covered with earth at the end of the day.

Methods used in controlled tipping are:

  • Trench method: Done in places where level ground is available
  • Ramp method: Well suited where the terrain is moderately sloping
  • Area method: Used for filling land depressions, disused quarries, and clay pits

questions.text: Which of the following patients with AML has a better prognosis than the others?

choices.text: A 48-year-old man newly diagnosed with AML with a family history of lymphoma
A 60-year-old woman who developed AML following chemotherapy for ovarian cancer
A 71-year-old man with a longstanding history of myelodysplastic syndrome
A 67-year-old woman evaluated with a 4-month history of pancytopenia prior to diagnosis

questions.solution:
Young age of onset is associated with a good prognosis in patients with AML. Family history does not affect the prognosis.

Poor prognosis is seen in the following cases:

  • Advancing age (usually defined as > 60 years) 
  • Previous hematologic disorders - myeloproliferative neoplasms and myelodysplastic syndrome
  • Longstanding cytopenias >3 months before diagnosis 
  • Therapy-related AML (chemotherapy for other cancers)
  • Chromosomal aberrations with poor outcomes

questions.text: A middle-aged man on treatment for lepromatous leprosy presents with the following painful lesions for one month. On examination, glove and stocking pattern of anesthesia is noted. What is the drug of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario points to a diagnosis of erythema nodosum leprosum or type 2 lepra reaction. The drug of choice is oral corticosteroids.

Clofazimine is indicated in chronic ENL, which is steroid-refractory or when steroids are contraindicated.

Thalidomide is superior to steroids in controlling ENL and can be used for severe ENL in young men. However, it is generally avoided in women due to its devastating teratogenic side effects. It may be considered in severe ENL but must be used cautiously, with double contraception measures. It also causes peripheral neuropathy and, hence, would be avoided in this patient with lepromatous neuropathy. The high cost and restricted availability also limit the use of this drug. 

Rifampicin should be avoided as it is highly bactericidal. The massive release of bacterial antigens may aggravate the lepra reaction.

questions.text: An ASHA worker is offering services under the Swachh Bharat Abhiyan in her village. All of the following services will be provided by her except:

choices.text: Information, education, communication and public awareness

questions.solution:
Water pollution is not managed under the Swachh Bharat Abhiyan.

The Swachh Bharat Abhiyan was launched in 2014 with an aim to eradicate open-air defecation by the year 2019 through the construction of 12 million toilets. The two sub-missions of Swachh Bharat Abhiyan are Swachh Bharat Mission Gramin (SBM-G) and Swachh Bharat Mission Urban (SBM-U).

  • Components of this mission include:
    • Household toilets including improving unsanitary latrines
    • Community toilets
    • Public toilets
    • Solid waste management
    • Information, education, communication, and public awareness
    • Capacity building and administrative & office expenses

questions.text: The nephrectomy specimen of a tumor of a 40-year-old man shows the following histological presentation. Which of the following familial cancer syndromes is this condition associated with?

choices.text: Hereditary leiomyomatosis and renal cell cancer syndrome

questions.solution:
The given image shows eosinophilic cells with prominent cell membranes and perinuclear halo, which is suggestive of chromophobe cell renal cell carcinoma (RCC). It is associated with Birt–Hogg–Dubé syndrome.

Other familial cancer syndromes and the common malignancies associated with them are:

  • Hereditary leiomyomatosis and renal cell cancer syndrome - papillary RCC
    • Large cells with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm, large nuclei, and prominent inclusion-like eosinophilic nucleoli.
  • Tuberous sclerosis - clear-cell RCC
  • Von Hippel–Lindau syndrome (VHL) - clear-cell RCC

The image given below shows the histology of chromophobe cell RCC.

Related Pearl: Familial renal cell carcinoma syndromes

questions.text: You are prescribing estrogen therapy for a woman with hot flushes. What is the minimum number of days in a month during which you should combine it with progesterone?
questions.solution:
A minimum of 12 days (in a month) of progesterone must be added to estrogen therapy. This reduces the risk of endometrial cancer to 2%. 

The risk of cancer with estrogen therapy is dose and duration-dependent. Combined estrogen and progesterone provides better protection against endometrial cancer. 

Tibolone is a safe drug and does not cause endometrial hyperplasia.

questions.text: Which of the following is the numerator in the formula for population-attributable risk?

choices.text: Incidence among exposed minus incidence among non-exposed
Incidence among non-exposed minus incidence among exposed
Incidence in the total population minus incidence among non-exposed
Incidence in the total population minus incidence among exposed

questions.solution:
Incidence in the total population minus incidence among non-exposed is the numerator in population-attributable risk (PAR).

Population attributable risk is obtained from cohort studies. It provides an estimate of the amount by which the disease could be reduced in that population if the suspected factor was eliminated or modified.

questions.text: A baby was born with a congenital defect as shown below. Which of the following statements is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: It is due to failure of physiological hernia to reduce before 7 weeks
Topical application of silver nitrate is done

questions.solution:
The congenital defect showing herniation of the intestinal contents enclosed in a sac from the umbilicus is suggestive of omphalocele. It is due to the failure of the physiological hernia to reduce into the abdominal cavity before 10 weeks resulting in non-closure of the umbilical ring. 

Physiological herniation of the midgut through the umbilicus occurs during the 5th week so as to accommodate the rapidly growing intestine and persists until the 10th week.

Omphalocele is seen in term babies and is usually associated with other congenital anomalies (e.g., trisomy 13, trisomy 18, or Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome) and with increased levels of α-fetoprotein.

An omphalocele may contain the stomach, liver, and intestines. These contents are enclosed in a sac. 

The treatment is as follows:

  • Preservation of the intact sac with a sterile, moistened, saline gauze or transparent bowel bag.
  • IV fluids should be started, along with gastric tube decompression and IV antibiotics.
  • Topical application of povidone-iodine ointment, merbromin (mercurochrome), or silver nitrate allows the sac to thicken and epithelialize gradually.
  • Primary surgical closure is preferred for small to medium-sized defects. 

Related Pearl: Difference between gastroschisis and omphalocele

Characteristic Gastroschisis Omphalocele
Defect size (diameter) 2-3 cm 2-15 cm
Sac Never Always, may be ruptured
Gestational age Prematurity Term
Umbilical cord Adjacent to the defect (defect is seen usually on its right side)  Attached to sac
Herniated viscera Small bowel, stomach, colon Small bowel, stomach, colon, liver
Malrotation Yes Yes
Bowel character Inflammatory, edematous Normal
Enternal nutrition Delayed Normal
Associated abnormalities Uncommon (10% atresia) Common (50%)

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about retrosternal goitre?

choices.text: Operated in all patients regardless of symptoms
Sternal incision is always required to operate
It receives blood supply from the thoracodorsal artery
Most of the retrosternal goitres can be removed by a neck incision

questions.solution:
Most of the retrosternal goiters can be removed by neck incision (transcervical approach).

Retrosternal goitre is defined as having >50% of the goiter below the suprasternal notch. It can be either primary or secondary.

  • Primary: rare and arises from ectopic thyroid tissue in the mediastinum; receives blood supply from intrathoracic blood vessels. It is not related to thyroid tissue in the neck.
  • Secondary: they are the most common type; an extension of enlarged thyroid from the neck, usually arising from the lower pole of nodular goitre. It receives its blood supply from superior and inferior thyroid vessels.

The majority of patients are asymptomatic or have minimal symptoms. If the gland enlarges within the thoracic inlet, the pressure may lead to dysphagia, tracheal compression, and eventually airway symptoms. Pemberton sign can be positive (facial flushing and dilatation of cervical veins upon raising the arms above the head).

CECT neck and thorax is the investigation of choice.

Over 95% of retrosternal goiters can be removed via a transcervical incision since they are an extension from thyroid tissue in the neck.

Other options:

Option A: Surgical removal of the retrosternal goiter is indicated in patients with significant airway compression, and in young patients who have symptoms such as dyspnoea or dysphagia. 

Option B: Median sternotomy approach is indicated in:

  • Primary mediastinal goiter
  • Malignant retrosternal goitre
  • Very large retrosternal goiter
  • Recurrence in the mediastinum

For a primary mediastinal goiter whose boundaries are completely within the chest, resection is often achieved through median sternotomy or thoracotomy to ensure that the vessels supplying the tumor are properly ligated. Removing the tumor through a cervical approach can result in uncontrolled bleeding and is generally avoided. 

Option C: Blood supply to the retrosternal goiter is from the thyroid vessels (secondary retrosternal goiter).

questions.text: Which of the following areas of the anterior surface of the right kidney is separated by a layer of peritoneum?
questions.solution:
The anterior surface of the right kidney related to the right lobe of the liver (marked as 1) is separated by a layer of peritoneum.

As the kidneys are located retroperitoneally, intraperitoneal anterior relations are separated from it by a peritoneal layer. 

The anterior relations of the right kidney:

Intraperitoneal
  • Right lobe of liver
  • Small intestine
Retroperitoneal 
  • Right suprarenal gland
  • 2nd part of duoednum  
  • Hepatic flexure of colon

questions.text: A patient comes to the OPD with a history significant of a mood disorder. His moods can be charted as shown in the image. What will be the best drug for him?
questions.solution:
The patient has rapid-cycling bipolar disorder. Sodium valproate is the drug of choice for this disorder.

Diagnosis of rapid-cycling bipolar disorder:

  • 4 or more mood disturbances in a year

Episodes either have a partial or full remission for at least 2 months or switch to the opposite polarity

Other options:

Option A: Lamotrigine has been found to have limited uses in rapid-cycling bipolar disorder. It can prolong the time between depression and mania.

Option C: Carbamazepine takes 2-3 weeks for the onset of action and is used in patients not responding to Lithium in Acute Mania.

Option D: Lithium takes 5-7 days to achieve a level of equilibrium, moreover it is effective in Bipolar I disorder and is less efficacious than Divalproex in rapid-cycling bipolar disorder.

 

A recent trial found that increased levels of parathyroid hormone in patients with bipolar disorder were associated with worse clinical outcomes. Researchers suggest vitamin D supplementation as a possible add-on treatment.

Related Pearl: Patterns of Mood Disorders

questions.text: Shreya, a 2-year-old girl, presented with irritability for 2 days. On examination, macrocephaly, hypotonia and spasticity were present with a positive head transillumination test. She started walking independently at 18 months and became dry by day a month before her 2nd birthday. An MRI-brain revealed cystic expansion of the fourth ventricle and midline cerebellar hypoplasia. What is the most likely diagnosis explaining her obstructive hydrocephalus?
questions.solution:
The features of hydrocephalus like irritability along with macrocephaly, hypotonia and spasticity indicate a likely diagnosis of Dandy-Walker syndrome. A positive transillumination test is present in this syndrome. The child has developmental delay especially in motor and cognitive milestones because normally children walk independently at 12-13 months and become dry by day around 18 months.

The Dandy-Walker malformation consists of a cystic expansion of the fourth ventricle in the posterior fossa and midline cerebellar hypoplasia. It results from a developmental failure of the roof of the fourth ventricle during embryogenesis. Most of the affected patients have hydrocephalus, agenesis of the posterior cerebellar vermis, and corpus callosum. Brisk tendon reflexes, spasticity, clonus, Babinski sign, cerebellar ataxia, and delayed motor and cognitive milestones are seen in this. Management is by shunting if hydrocephalus is present.

The image below shows a sagittal section of the magnetic resonance tomography scan of a patient with Dandy-Walker syndrome.

questions.text: A patient with chronic adrenal insufficiency is on long term corticosteroid therapy. Which of the following side effects is he unlikely to experience?
questions.solution:
Corticosteroid therapy does not cause muscular hypertrophy and the patient is unlikely to experience it as a side effect.

Excess glucocorticoid activity results in muscle wasting and myopathy while excess mineralocorticoid activity results in hypokalemia and causes muscle weakness.

Options B and C: Peptic ulceration and psychosis are known adverse effects of corticosteroids.

Option D: Glucocorticoids with some mineralocorticoid activity will result in sodium and water retention and may cause hypertension.

Related Pearl: Side effects of Corticosteroids: mnemonic "CORTICOSTEROIDS"

The mnemonic is "CORTICOSTEROIDS"

C - Cushing’s syndrome

O - Osteoporosis

R - Retardation of growth

T - Thin skin and easy bruisability

I - Infections and immunosuppression

C - Cataract

O - Oedema

S - Suppression of HPA axis

T - Thinning and ulceration of gastric mucosa

E - Emotional disturbance

R - Rise in BP

O - Others fatal abnormalities like hypokalemia

D - Diabetes mellitus precipitation

questions.text: What is the pathological basis for the given skin finding?
questions.solution:
The image is suggestive of vitiligo. The pathological basis of vitiligo is the loss of melanocytes.

Vitiligo is a common form of localized depigmentation. It is characterized by milky‐white sharply demarcated macules. It is an acquired condition resulting from the autoimmune destruction of dopa-positive melanocytes in the basal layer of the epidermis.

Vitiligo can begin at any age but in the majority of cases becomes apparent in the third decade. The prevalence is most probably the same in both sexes or a slight female preponderance.

Electron microscopy studies confirm the loss of melanocytes. Wood's lamp examination shows milky-white fluorescence.

Koebner phenomenon defined as the development of lesions at sites of trauma to uninvolved skin of patients with cutaneous diseases is a well‐known phenomenon in vitiligo.

 

World Vitiligo day is celebrated every year on 25th June to promote understanding and help vitiligo patients avoid discrimination and become more optimistic in life. The theme for the year 2021 is "Embracing Life with Vitiligo".

questions.text: Which of the following is a marker of the heat stability of vaccines?
questions.solution:
Vaccine Vial Monitors (VVM) are heat-sensitive indicators that are routinely used to monitor vaccine viability as the vaccine vial moves across the supply chain.

VVM records cumulative heat exposure through a gradual change in color. If the color of the inner square is the same or is darker than the outer circle, the vaccine has been exposed to too much temperature and should be discarded.

Related Pearl: Vaccine Vial Monitors

  • Vaccine vial monitors are used to monitor heat exposure of vaccines.
  • It is a chemical indicator that records the cumulative heat exposure through a gradual change in color.
  • If the color of the inner square is the same color or darker than the outer circle, it indicates that the vaccine has been exposed to too much heat and it must be discarded.
  • Currently, there are four types of VVMs (VVM2, VVM7, VVM14, and VVM30). They are chosen to match the heat sensitivity of the vaccine.
  • The VVM can be located on the label of the vaccine or on the neck or cap of the ampule/vial.
  • VVMs also help in reduction of vaccine wastage by indicating which batch of vaccines can be used first.

Related Pearl: Temperature Sensitivity of Vaccines

questions.text: In an intubated patient, after what duration of endotracheal intubation will you need to perform a tracheostomy?
questions.solution:
Tracheostomy is performed in an intubated patient after 2-3 weeks.

This is because if an orotracheal or nasotracheal tube is left in situ for more than 2-3 weeks, it results in subglottic stenosis.

Hence it is ideal to replace the endotracheal tube with a cuffed tracheostomy tube.

If on intubation, it is perceived that the patient may require intubation for a period longer than 2 weeks, then tracheostomy can be performed soon after intubation.

Tracheostomy has been found to reduce the incidence of pneumonia, the duration of mechanical ventilation, and the length of stay in hospitals for patients with major head injuries.

questions.text: Addition of 500 mL of hypertonic saline to the extracellular fluid leads to _______
questions.solution:
The images shown in the figure are called Darrow Yannet Diagrams. They depict the change in plasma osmolality and plasma volume in various conditions.

If a hypertonic solution is added to the extracellular fluid, the extracellular osmolarity increases and causes osmosis of water out of the cells into the extracellular compartment

  • ECF osmolality increases. ECF volume increases.
  • As, ECF osmolality rises, fluid from ICF moves to ECF till osmotic equilibrium is established. So,
  • ICF osmolality rises. ICF volume decreases.

Therefore, the net effect is an increase in extracellular volume (greater than the volume of fluid added), a decrease in intracellular volume, and a rise in osmolarity in both compartments.

Note : The dotted line in the diagram is the change after either addition or removal of fluid

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought to the casualty with severe abdominal pain. On performing emergency exploratory laparotomy, the following finding is noted. Which of the following statements is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: Can be a lead point for intussusception
The most common presenting symptom is bleeding in younger children
It is a false diverticulum which extends from the anti-mesenteric side
Most common heterotopic tissue is gastric mucosa

questions.solution:
Meckel’s diverticulum is a true diverticulum, which extends from the antimesenteric side of the small bowel. The diverticula which contain all the layers of the intestine are called true diverticula. 

Meckel’s diverticulum is caused by a failure of normal regression of the vitelline duct that develops during weeks 5-7 of gestation.

The rule of 2's (Mnemonic for Meckel’s diverticulum) :

  • 2 types of heterotopic mucosa (gastric & pancreatic)
  • 2% incidence
  • located within 2 feet of the ileocecal valve
  • approximately 2 inches in length
  • Usually symptomatic by 2 years of age

The most common presentation is painless, massive, lower GI bleed in children younger than 5 years. Meckel's diverticulum can be the lead point for ileoileal or ileocolic intussusception.

A bleeding Meckel's diverticulum may be confirmed by a 99 mTc-pertechnetate isotope scan to detect ectopic gastric mucosa. 

Surgical treatment is the definitive therapy for Meckel’s diverticulum. A simple V-shaped diverticulectomy with transverse closure of the ileum is the ideal surgical approach.

The following diagram shows the various anomalies that arise as a result of the failure of normal regression of vitellointestinal duct:

questions.text: While planning thrombolysis for a patient with MI, use of which of the following agents will reduce the chances of a dosing error?
questions.solution:
Tenecteplase is given as a single bolus dose (based on body weight) which reduces the rate of medication errors (common with IV infusions).

Tenecteplase and reteplase are referred to as bolus fibrinolytics as their administration does not require prolonged intravenous infusion. 

Related Pearl: Plasminogen activators (classification of fibrinolytics)

Fibrin non-specific plasminogen activators

  • Streptokinase - least fibrin specific and has the lowest incidence of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Anistreplase
  • Urokinase

Fibrin specific plasminogen activators

  • Alteplase - has the shortest half-life
  • Tenecteplase - most fibrin specific and given as a single bolus dose
  • Reteplase

questions.text: An 8-year-old child presents with grade 2 splenic injury following blunt trauma to the abdomen. On examination, there are no signs of bleeding. Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this child?
questions.solution:
Conservative management is the most appropriate management in this child.

Selective Non-Operative Management (SNOM) is usually followed in:

  • Stable patients with no active bleeding
  • Patients younger than 55 years of age
  • Patients with grade I, II, III injuries.

Any patient who is hemodynamically unstable, has active bleeding, and has grade IV and V splenic injury should be managed by surgery.

Related Pearl: American Association for the Surgery of Trauma (AAST) Spleen Injury Scale

questions.text: What is the programme evaluation and review technique used for?
questions.solution:
The programme evaluation and review technique (PERT) is used for network analysis.

It is a type of quantitative management technique which helps in detailed planning and comprehensive supervision. 

Related Pearl: Network Analysis in Health Management

A network is a graphic plan of all events and activities to be completed in order to reach an end objective.

Two types of network analysis: PERT and CPM

1. Programme Evaluation and Review Technique (PERT)

  • An arrow diagram of all events in logical sequence is drawn.
  • Time to finish each activity can be calculated and critical activities can be identified.
  • It aids in planning, scheduling and monitoring of the project.

2. Critical Path Method (CPM)

  • The longest path of the network is called the critical path.
  • A delay in the critical path will cause a delay in the entire project.

questions.text: The correct order of steps in Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) is:
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of events for PCR among the given options is denaturation, annealing, and extension.

The process of PCR is as follows:

The DNA sample is first heat-denatured at >90°C (90-96 degrees Celsius for 3 minutes) to separate the two strands of the template DNA containing the target sequence; the primers (which attach to the 3' end of the flanking sequence) are added in excess, are allowed to anneal to the DNA (typically at 50-75°C) in order to generate the required template-primer hybridization complex. Under suitable conditions and presence of deoxynucleotides, elongation of the DNA stand occurs. 

The number of copies produced in the presence of an unlimited supply of deoxynucleotides and enzymes is given by - 2 to the power n (where n is the number of PCR cycles)

  • 20 cycles provide an amplification of 220 = 106  or 1 million copies
  • 30 cycles provides an amplification of 230 =109 or 1 billion copies

Below is an image showing the various ingredients for carrying out PCR.

questions.text: A patient with rheumatic heart disease now presents with fever and the following nail finding. The nail lesions most likely are?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of infective endocarditis (IE). Splinter hemorrhages are seen in the nails of these patients.

Subungual splinter hemorrhages are classically identified as dark-red, linear petechiae in the nail bed.

Other peripheral manifestations of infective endocarditis include the following:

  • Petechiae: Common but nonspecific finding
  • Purulent purpura
  • Osler nodes: Tender subcutaneous nodules usually found on the distal pads of the digits
  • Janeway lesions: Nontender maculae on the palms and soles
  • Roth spots: Relatively rare retinal hemorrhages with small, clear centers

questions.text: A 25-year-old man was referred for infertility evaluation. On examination, he was tall with a lack of body hair. Gynecomastia and micropenis were also noted. Karyotyping analysis revealed an XXY karyotype. Which of the following statements is not true about the condition?

choices.text: Levels of follicle-stimulating hormone are reduced

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Klinefelter's syndrome. In this condition, the follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) levels are elevated. 

The clinical features include:

  • Eunuchoid body habitus - elongated body and long legs (increased length between the soles and the pubic bone)
  • Absence of secondary sexual characteristics - lack of body and facial hair, deep voice
  • Small atrophic testes
  • Micropenis
  • Gynecomastia
  • Lower IQ, but no mental retardation

The following hormonal variations are seen in these patients:

  • Elevated FSH
  • Elevated estradiol
  • Low testosterone
  • Insulin resistance - increased incidence of type 2 diabetes

Patients with Klinefelter syndrome are at a higher risk for:

  • Male breast cancer (20x more common than in normal males)
  • Extragonadal germ cell tumors
  • Autoimmune diseases - systemic lupus erythematosus

questions.text: A patient presents to the ER with irrelevant slurred speech. On examination, a dry mouth, dry and hot skin, and dilated pupils are noted. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Datura poisoning.

The two species are jimson weed (Datura stramonium) and angel’s trumpet (Datura candida).

Seeds or other parts of the plant can be ingested or smoked. Poisoning leads to delirium, hallucinations, and seizures. Additionally, other classic anticholinergic effects, such as mydriasis, tachycardia, dry mouth and skin, blurred vision, urinary retention, and hyperthermia may present.

Gastric emptying is often delayed, and the small, plentiful seeds can become trapped among the gastrointestinal folds after ingestion. Thus gastric decontamination can be an important therapy.

Physostigmine, a reversible acetylcholine esterase antagonist, is an effective treatment for severe anticholinergic poisoning.

In India, the root and leaves of Jimsonweed (Datura) were burned and the smoke was inhaled to treat asthma. Around the 1800s, British colonists observed this and introduced the belladonna alkaloids in western medicine for the management of asthma.

questions.text: A 51-year-old man complains of abdominal pain and blood-stained stools. The barium study of his intestines shows the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the radiological images are suggestive of intussusception.

In intussusception, the occluding mass prolapsing into the lumen has been termed the coiled spring appearance (barium in the lumen of the intussusceptum and in the intraluminal space). In adults, it develops due to a tumor of the bowel.

The intussusception appears as a sausage-shaped mass in a longitudinal plane or a target mass in the transverse plane on CT and USG. 

Ultrasound signs include:

  • Target sign (also known as the doughnut sign)
  • Pseudokidney sign- this is seen in the longitudinal section of the bowel
    • the edematous bowel resembles renal parenchyma and
    • the mesentery which is dragged into the intussusception resembles renal hilum
  • Crescent in a doughnut sign.

Note: The colographic appearance of intussusception is also described as a claw sign, pincer defect, shouldering effect, and coiled-spring pattern.

Option B: Volvulus presents with constipation, abdominal bloating, nausea, and/or vomiting. It shows coffee bean sign

Option C: Diverticulitis presents with pain in the left iliac fossa

Option D: Ulcerative colitis causes backwash ileitis

questions.text: An anxious mother brought her 4-year-old-child to the hospital with complaints of sudden onset fever and refusal to eat. On examination, the given finding was noted and he was started on analgesics and antibiotics. Which among the following is not a known complication of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of acute tonsillitis. Excessive bleeding is not a known complication of this condition.

Complications of acute tonsillitis:

  • Chronic tonsillitis - chronic infection may persist in lymphoid follicles of the tonsil in the form of microabscesses
  • Peritonsillar abscess
  • Parapharyngeal abscess 
  • Cervical abscess due to suppuration of jugulodigastric lymph nodes
  • Acute otitis media
  • Rheumatic fever - often seen in association with tonsillitis due to group A β-hemolytic streptococci
  • Acute glomerulonephritis (rare)
  • Subacute bacterial endocarditis - acute tonsillitis in a patient with valvular heart disease may be complicated by endocarditis. It is usually due to Streptococcus viridans infection

questions.text: A college student came to the OPD with fever and muscle aches. He tells you he had consumed smoked pork at a party 2 weeks back. Following this, he had developed abdominal cramps and diarrhea which had resolved on their own. CBC revealed eosinophilia and the muscle biopsy showed the following finding. What is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
Abdominal cramps and diarrhea after consumption of smoked pork, followed by fever, muscle aches and eosinophilia 2 weeks later, with muscle biopsy showing encysted larvae are suggestive of trichinellosis. It is caused by Trichinella spiralis.

Trichinella spiralis, known as pork worm, is acquired by consuming raw or undercooked pork. The initial infection presents with diarrhea and abdominal pain. In the later phase of the infection, the larvae migrate from the intestines into the circulation and migrate into muscles. This leads to periorbital and facial edema, splinter hemorrhages and cough. Patients also have fever,  myalgia, muscle edema and weakness. These larvae are calcified in about 5-6 months.

Blood eosinophilia develops in most patients 2-4 weeks after infection. Serum levels of creatine phosphokinase are elevated. Spiral larvae are seen in muscle biopsy. Deltoid, biceps, gastrocnemius, or pectoralis muscles are usually selected for biopsy.

Other parasites that can be demonstrated in a muscle biopsy are Taenia solium and Trypanosoma cruzi (amastigote).

questions.text: A 51-year-old male patient came with complaints of hematuria to the clinic. On examination, he was normotensive and had pedal edema. Investigations revealed the patient had no glycosuria and had a creatinine of 9. His renal biopsy is shown below. Which of the following investigations should be done to identify the disease?
questions.solution:
Based on the given clinical history and microscopy showing crescents, rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN) is suspected. Among the given options, anti- GBM antibody testing should be done, since it is a part of the work-up of RPGN.

Type 1 RPGN includes renal limited disease and Goodpasture's disease. In this condition, antibodies are produced against the non-collagenous domain of the α3 chain of collagen IV of the GBM.

Microscopy findings of Goodpasture's disease are:

  • Immunofluorescence - linear deposits of Ig and complement along the glomerular basement membrane
  • Electron microscopy - wrinkling of the glomerular basement membrane with focal disruptions without any immune complex deposition.

A variant of Goodpasture's disease with pulmonary involvement is known as Goodpasture's syndrome.

Option A: ANA testing is done if SLE is suspected. Electron microscopy will show immune complex deposits.

Option C: HIV RNA testing is done in immunodeficiency syndrome associated with weight loss. Electron microscopy will show diffuse podocyte injury with complete foot process effacement. Tubuloreticular inclusions will be seen in endothelial cells.

Option D: Urine electrophoresis is done if nephrotic syndrome is suspected.

questions.text: A person with suspected marijuana consumption is brought by the police for urine drug testing. He claims single use of marijuana at a party. Up to how many days can the drug be detected in his urine?
questions.solution:
After a single use of marijuana, tetrahydrocannabinol (active principle of Cannabis) can be detected in urine tests for up to 3 days.

Marijuana or Cannabis consists of the dried flowering tops and leaves of the plant Cannabis sativa. Hashish is prepared from the resin of the stems and leaves of this plant.

With long-term use, cannabinoids can be detected up to 30 days or longer after abstinence.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presented with pain while walking after a prolonged flight travel. Ultrasonography revealed thrombus in the short saphenous vein. If the thrombus gets dislodged, it is likely to enter which of the following veins first?
questions.solution:
A thrombus in the short saphenous vein may get dislodged and enter the popliteal vein. The embolus may further travel into the right heart and eventually may cause a pulmonary embolism.

The short saphenous vein is the continuation of the lateral side of the dorsal venous arch. It passes behind the lateral malleolus and drains into the popliteal vein in the popliteal fossa. The popliteal vein continues as the femoral vein proximal to the knee.

The image given below shows the venous drainage of the lower limb.

questions.text: A young boy from high altitude came with fever and weakness and had the following reports - Hemoglobin 17 g%, TLC is 21,000 with neutrophils 25, lymphocytes 30, eosinophils 5, myelocytes and metamyelocytes 40 in peripheral smear. Next step in the investigation should be:

choices.text: Bone Marrow biopsy with reticulin stain

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of polycythemia (Hb>16 g/dL). Hence, erythropoietin levels (EPO) are estimated next, to differentiate between primary or secondary polycythemia. Based on EPO levels:

  • Primary polycythemia - normal/ decreased
  • Secondary polycythemia - increased

Options A and B: JAK 2 mutation and Philadelphia chromosome analysis is only done as a last resort.

Option D: Bone marrow estimation with reticulin is done for myelofibrosis which can be seen in the spent/ late stage of the disease. However, peripheral smear findings are not suggestive of primary myelofibrosis. Leukoerythroblastic reaction with dacrocytes is seen in myelofibrosis.

Diagnosis of polycythemia vera requires meeting either all 3 major criteria or the first 2 major criteria along with the minor criterion

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman from a tribal area presented with fever, chills, malaise, fatigue, and headache for the past 3 days. The peripheral blood smear examination is as shown in the image. Which of the following is false regarding the causative agent?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing ring forms/ early trophozoites in erythrocytes, which are binucleate resembling stereo headphones in appearance, are characteristic of P. falciparum malaria. Hypnozoites are absent in P. falciparum infection.

Malaria is a parasitic infection caused by the Plasmodium species transmitted by the Anopheles mosquito. It is characterized by many nonspecific symptoms, including but not limited to tachycardia, tachypnea, chills, malaise, fatigue, diaphoresis (sweating), and headache. The fever of malaria is characterized by periodicity depending on the infective Plasmodium species. The fever returns every other day for Plasmodium vivax, Plasmodium ovale, and Plasmodium falciparum, and every three days for P. malariae. 

The peripheral smear finding of P. falciparum malaria are:

  • Normal size RBCs
  • Multiple ring form
  • Accole form
  • Absent schizont
  • Banana shaped gametocytes
  • Maurer's dots

The below image shows banana shaped gametocyte:

questions.text: A medical student skipped breakfast to be able to attend his morning class. He is currently thinking about having food and coffee after class, and notices increased salivary secretion. The nerve fibres to the parotid gland responsible for this come from all except:
questions.solution:
The given case scenario is suggestive of parasympathetic stimulation of the salivary glands, causing the parasympathetic secretomotor fibres to increase salivary secretion.

The parasympathetic fibres to the parotid gland are carried by the lesser petrosal nerve.

Otic ganglion is a parasympathetic ganglion which supplies secretomotor fibres to the parotid gland and is present below the foramen ovale. 

  • Preganglionic fibres originate in the inferior salivatory nucleus and pass through the lesser petrosal nerve which is the continuation of the tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve. They relay in the otic ganglion.
  • Postganglionic fibres pass by the communicating branches to the auriculotemporal nerve and supply the parotid gland.

The greater petrosal nerve carries secretomotor fibres to the pterygopalatine ganglion and supplies the lacrimal, nasal, and palatine glands.

Sympathetic supply to the parotid gland is derived from the plexus around the middle meningeal artery.

Sensory supply to the parotid gland is from the auriculotemporal nerve and to the parotid capsule is from the sensory fibres of greater auricular nerve.

Related Pearl: Parasympathetic/ secretomotor (general visceral efferent) innervation of glands

  • Nervus intermedius, also called the nerve of Wrisberg, is the sensory & secretomotor component of the facial nerve.
  • The main trunk of the facial nerve, as it exits the brainstem, only carries motor fibers.

questions.text:
Which of the following structures of HBV aid in the survival of HDV?

HBV - Hepatitis B virus
HDV - Hepatitis D virus
questions.solution:
Hepatitis D virus (HDV) is an incomplete/defective virus. It requires HBV, to provide the envelope protein (HbsAg) to aid in its survival. Hepatitis D is called the delta virus.

Two types of infection may occur:  

  • Co-infection - acute HDV and HBV infections occur simultaneously
  • Super-infection - Delta viral infection occurs in a person already harboring HBV. This most often leads to chronic hepatitis

Coinfection and superinfection can cause fulminant hepatitis. HBV vaccination is protective against HDV.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female patient is undergoing focussed parathyroidectomy for parathyroid adenoma. According to the Miami criteria, for the resection to be considered adequate, the intraoperative drop in parathyroid hormone should be ______.

choices.text: More than one third  the maximum preoperative value in 10min
More than one third  the maximum preoperative value in half an 30 min
More than half  the maximum preoperative value in 10min
More than half  the maximum preoperative value in 30 min

questions.solution:
Drop of parathyroid hormone to more than half the maximum value at 10 min postresection is considered an adequate resection in a parathyroid adenoma by the Miami criteria.

Most of the patients with primary hyperparathyroidism have single adenoma, and therefore undergo a focused or minimally invasive parathyroidectomy, where the localized abnormal parathyroid gland is removed. Once the gland is removed, the surgeon can ensure that there is no other hyperactive gland remaining by performing an intraoperative PTH assay for Miami criteria.

It is based on the principle that the half-life of the PTH is 3-5 minutes. In a single-gland disease, once the gland is removed the PTH levels should drop to >50% of the preoperative PTH level within 10 minutes. However, if there is no drop in PTH level, then a multi-gland disease is suspected and the surgery is converted to a bilateral neck exploration.

questions.text: What is not included in the definition of a suspect case of SARS-CoV-2?
questions.solution:
All of the given symptoms are included in the definition of a suspect case of SARS-CoV-2/COVID-19 except convulsions.

As per WHO and MOHFW, a suspect case is defined as:

  1. A person who meets the clinical and epidemiological criteria-
    1. Clinical criteria:
      • Acute onset of fever AND cough; OR
      • Acute onset of any 3 or more of the following: fever, cough, general weakness/ fatigue, headache, myalgia, sore throat, coryza, dyspnoea, anorexia/nausea/vomiting, diarrhea, altered mental status.
    2. Epidemiological criteria: A person present in any of the following settings for 14 days prior to symptom onset-
      • Residing or working in an area with a high risk of transmission of virus OR
      • Residing or travel to an area with community transmission OR
      • Working in any healthcare setting
  2. A patient with severe acute respiratory illness with-
    • history of fever or measured fever of ≥38 C° along with cough
    • onset within the last 10 days
    • requiring hospitalization
  3. An asymptomatic person not meeting epidemiologic criteria with a positive SARS-CoV-2 antigen-RDT.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presented to the casualty with vomiting and severe colicky pain in the abdomen for the past 48 hours. She had undergone a weight reduction surgery six months ago and had achieved around 30% weight loss. Her plain X-ray abdomen is given below. Which of the following bariatric procedures was most likely done in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and radiograph (dilated bowel segments with valvulae conniventes in the left upper quadrant) are suggestive of small bowel obstruction. Bariatric surgery, specifically, Roux-en-Y gastric bypass surgery is associated with the creation of mesenteric defects. The small bowel can herniate through these defects (internal hernia) and get strangulated, resulting in bowel obstruction. 

In addition, as the person loses weight (due to the bariatric procedure), the protective, space-occupying effect of the mesenteric fat is lost and hernia spaces open up, further increasing the risk of internal hernia. The laparoscopic procedure has a higher risk compared to open surgery since fewer adhesions form to tether small-bowel loops and prevent them from herniating. 

Adequate closure of the mesenteric defects by the surgeon at the time of operation significantly reduces the risk of internal hernia.

Other complications specific to Roux-en-Y gastric bypass:

  • Nutritional deficiencies: iron (most common), folate, Vitamin A, D, K and B12      
  • Anastomosis site leak      
  • Bleeding from the site of gastrojejunostomy   
  • Dumping syndrome
  • Marginal ulcers
  • Increased risk of DVT and pulmonary embolism

Option A: Sleeve gastrectomy is often complicated by staple line leak.

Option B: Laparoscopic adjustable gastric banding is associated with band slippage and erosion.

Option D: Endoluminal stapling is also used to create a gastric sleeve. It is associated with postoperative nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, and transient dysphagia.

questions.text:
Identify the correct sequence of the auditory pathways:
A.Superior Olivary nucleus
B. Cochlear Nucleus
C. Inferior Colliculi
D. Lateral lemniscus
E. Medial geniculate ganglion
questions.solution:
Cochlear nucleus (B), superior olivary nucleus (A), lateral lemniscus (D), inferior colliculi (C), and medial geniculate ganglion (E) represent the correct sequence of the auditory pathway.

The correct sequence of structures involved in the auditory pathway from the periphery to the center is 

  1. Vestibulocochlear nerve
  2. Cochlear Nucleus
  3. Superior olivary nucleus
  4. Lateral lemniscus
  5. Inferior colliculus
  6. Medial geniculate body
  7. Auditory cortex

Related Pearl: BERA (Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry) or ABR (Auditory Brainstem Response)

It is an objective test that records electrical activity occurring in the auditory pathway.

Normally, 7 waves are produced in the first 10ms. 

  • Wave I – distal part of the cochlear nerve
  • Wave II –proximal part of the cochlear nerve
  • Wave III – cochlear nucleus
  • Wave IV – superior olivary complex
  • Wave V – lateral lemniscus
  • Wave VI & VII – inferior colliculus

Findings:

  • Conductive or cochlear pathology- delayed wave-I but inter-peak latency of I-V is normal
  • Retrocochlear pathology- wave-I present, rest of the waves absent
  • Acoustic neuroma or vestibular schwannoma- increased inter-peak latency of wave I-V and increased inter-aural latency of wave V > 0.2ms.

Uses:

  • To objectively find hearing threshold- wave-V appears 10dB above the hearing level obtained through PTA
  • Best audiometric test for:
    • Confirming hearing loss in infants
    • Diagnosing acoustic neuroma
    • Differentiating cochlear and retro-cochlear hearing loss
    • Diagnosing non-organic hearing loss.

questions.text: A 20-year-old college student presented with complaints of facial pain, nasal discharge, headache, and nasal bleeding. He has a history of recurrent sinusitis in the past. On anterior rhinoscopy examination, the nasal septum is deviated. Which of the following is the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is a case of deviated nasal septum and septoplasty is the treatment of choice.

Both submucous resection and septoplasty can be done for DNS. Septoplasty is a conservative approach and more commonly done nowadays. Septoplasty is also the preferred surgery for DNS in less than 18 yrs, if DNS is bilateral and severe.

questions.text: A patient who had just undergone electro-convulsive therapy presented to the casualty with pain over the shoulder.  The arm was held in internal rotation and could not be rotated back to the normal position. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history and clinical features are suggestive of posterior dislocation of shoulder. 

Posterior dislocation of the shoulder usually occurs with an indirect force causing marked internal rotation and adduction. This condition can be seen after a convulsion, or an electric shock. It can also occur after a fall on the flexed and adducted arm, or after a direct blow to the front of the shoulder.

The classical attitude of the arm is internal rotation and locked in that position. The examiner will be unable to externally rotate the arm back to normal position.

questions.text: Which of the following esophageal carcinomas is most likely to develop in patients with long-standing achalasia cardia?
questions.solution:
The most common type of carcinoma associated with this condition is squamous cell carcinoma.

Achalasia is a premalignant condition. It becomes malignant due to long-standing, retained, undigested fermenting food in the body of the esophagus, causing mucosal irritation.

Adenocarcinoma may also arise in the setting of achalasia but is less common as compared to SCC.

Small cell carcinoma is a rare type of neuroendocrine esophageal carcinoma more common in the lower esophagus. It is very aggressive and the 5-year survival rate is 8%. 

Carcinoid tumors are slow-growing tumors of neuroendocrine cells that form in the  GI tract, mainly in the rectum, small intestine, or appendix.

questions.text: Stearic acid is converted into which of the following fatty acids by the enzyme △9  desaturase?
questions.solution:
Stearic acid is converted to oleic acid by the enzyme △9 desaturase.

△9 desaturase is present in the endoplasmic reticulum. It catalyzes the synthesis of monounsaturated fatty acids (Eg: Oleic acid) from saturated fatty acids (Eg: Stearic acid). △9 desaturase is a mixed-function oxidase, requiring NADPH and O2. The first double bond is always introduced in the △9 positions. Humans cannot introduce double bonds beyond △9 positions (between C-10 and terminal methyl group). Hence, linoleic (Δ9,12) and linolenic acid (Δ9,12,15) are considered essential fatty acids and should be included in the diet.

Oleic acid has unsaturation at the △9 position. This can be memorized as 9 letters in oleic acid ( O-L-E-I-C  A-C-I-D)

questions.text: A 50-year-old man, under treatment for hypertension for the past two months, is found to have a blood pressure of 144/96 mmHg. How will you grade it according to the European society of cardiology guidelines-2018?
questions.solution:
According to the European society of cardiology guidelines-2018, a patient having a systolic BP≥140 and a diastolic BP≥90 mmHg is classified as having grade 1 hypertension.

questions.text: A patient was scheduled to undergo a vaginal hysterectomy procedure under epidural anaesthesia. 5 minutes after the epidural block was given, the patient started shivering. Which of the following is false regarding post-neuraxial shivering?

choices.text: Is not a sign of malignant hyperthermia
More common with spinal than epidural anesthesia
I.V. meperidine is used for treatment

questions.solution:
Post-neuraxial shivering is more common with epidural than spinal anaesthesia.

The possible reasons include the use of a large volume of cold epidural injectate as compared to a small volume of spinal drug and the inability to shiver with spinal anaesthesia because of the profound motor block as compared with epidural techniques.

Post-neuraxial shivering:

  • The incidence of post-neuraxial shivering is more than 40% (~55%)
  • The addition of neuraxial opioids (fentanyl, pethidine) reduces the likelihood of shivering
  • Prewarming the patient with a forced-air warmer and avoiding the administration of cold epidural and intravenous fluids helps to prevent shivering
  • It has no relation to malignant hyperthermia
  • Intravenous meperidine and tramadol are used in the treatment

questions.text: You are examining a 29-year-old man with the following painless indurated lesion. Which of the following is not a feature of this condition, if left untreated?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a painless ulcer with indurated margins is suggestive of primary syphilis. It is Secondary Syphilis that causes non-scarring alopecia that appear as moth-eaten patches if left untreated

The incubation period of syphilis is 9-90 days and varies inversely with the size of the Spirochaete inoculum. 

Primary chancre: Painless, indurated, button-like ulcer with painless lymphadenopathy.

Secondary syphilis: Roseolar rash is the earliest sign, but it is hard to see in dark-skinned people. When it fades, it leaves depigmented spots. This is called the necklace of Venus as it commonly occurs around the neck. Generalized papular lesions also occur. Sometimes these papules form a line along the hair margin called Corona Veneris or crown of Venus.

In latent syphilis, there are no features of active disease, but serological tests are positive. It can last up to 20 years.

Tertiary syphilis: Begins with skin nodules or the characteristic gumma which occurs 3-10 years after infection. The name arises from the necrotic center which may turn into a slimy, stringy mass.

questions.text: During rounds in the postnatal ward, you notice a patient's case sheet mentioning she had uterine tachysystole following labor induction. What is the criteria for this diagnosis?

choices.text: More than  5 contractions in a 5-min period
More than 5 contractions in a 10-min period
More than 10 contractions in a 5-min period
More than 10 contractions in a 10-min period

questions.solution:
Uterine tachysystole is defined as >5 contractions in a 10 min period and may occur in spontaneous or stimulated labor. It should always be qualified by the presence or absence of fetal heart rate abnormalities. Tachysystole interrupts maternal blood flow to the placenta during contractions and may lead to a reduction in fetal oxygenation. It is also associated with placental abruption.

It is caused by pharmacological agents used for cervical ripening and induction such as misoprostol (both oral and vaginal) and dinoprostone. Management includes stopping oxytocin infusion and terbutaline 0.25 mg SC.
