questions.text: A 55-year-old woman had an autonomic neuropathy that disrupted the sympathetic nerve supply to the pupillary dilator muscle of her right eye. While having her eyes examined, the ophthalmologist placed a sympathomimetic drug in both her eyes. The right eye became much more dilated than the left  eye. This suggests that:

choices.text: The sympathetic nerve to the right eye had regenerated
The parasympathetic nerve supply to the right eye remained intact and compensated for the loss of the sympathetic nerve
The left eye also had nerve damage and so was not responding as expected

questions.solution:
Denervation supersensitivity develops in the muscle after the nerve supplying it is cut. Since the nerve to her right dilator pupillae is damaged, the right eye becomes excessively sensitive to the sympathomimetic drug. So, the right eye becomes much more dilated than the left.

Denervation Supersensitivity:

  • When the motor nerve to skeletal muscle is degenerated, the muscle gradually becomes extremely sensitive to acetylcholine. This is called denervation hypersensitivity or supersensitivity.
  • Normally nicotinic receptors are located only in the vicinity of the motor endplate where the axon of the motor nerve terminates. When the motor nerve is severed, there is a marked proliferation of nicotinic receptors over a wide region of the neuromuscular junction.
  • Denervation supersensitivity also occurs at autonomic junctions. Smooth muscle, unlike skeletal muscle, does not atrophy when denervated, but it becomes hyperresponsive to the chemical mediator that normally activates it.
  • This hyperresponsiveness can be demonstrated by using pharmacologic tools rather than actual nerve section. Prolonged use of a drug such as reserpine can be used to deplete transmitter stores and prevent the target organ from being exposed to norepinephrine for an extended period. Once the drug usage is stopped, smooth muscle and cardiac muscle will be supersensitive to subsequent release of the neurotransmitter.

Option a) If the symapthetic nerve would have regenerated, both right and left eye would have been equally sensitive to the drug and so, would have dilated equally.

Option b) Parasympathetic nerves supply the spinchter pupillae muscle. So, if stimulated they would constrict the eye not dilate it. Also, the drug added was a sympathomimetic agent. So, parasympathetic nerves are not stimulated in the first place

Option d) If the left eye was damaged, it would also have denervation supersensitivity. Again, both eyes would dilate equally, but more than that of normal.

questions.text: An elderly male presented with significant weight loss and an inability to swallow food. A barium swallow was done and showed the following. Which of the following statements is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: Dysphagia is the most common symptom
T1a tumor is restricted to sub mucosa
Barium swallow shows rat tail appearance
Flexible endoscopy with biopsy is used to confirm diagnosis

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with rat-tail appearance on barium swallow is suggestive of esophageal carcinoma. T1a tumor is restricted to the muscularis mucosa.

Esophageal carcinoma is more commonly seen in men. Tobacco use and alcohol are strong risk factors. Adenocarcinoma and squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus are the two most common types. 

Clinical features include:

  • Dysphagia (most common)
  • Regurgitation
  • Vomiting
  • Odynophagia
  • Weight loss

In the advanced stage, there can be hoarseness of voice due to recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy, horner’s syndrome, chronic spinal pain, and diaphragmatic paralysis.

 Flexible endoscopy with biopsy is preferred for confirmation of diagnosis. Other Investigations include barium swallow which shows a rat-tail appearance  due to irregular narrowing or ulceration. Contrast-enhanced CT and PET can be used to assess distant metastasis. Endoscopic ultrasonography (EUS) is the investigation of choice to assess tumor invasion and lymph node metastasis.

 

TNM staging:

Primary Tumor (T)

TX

Tumor cannot be assessed

T0

No evidence of tumor

Tis

High-grade dysplasia

T1

Tumor invades the muscularis mucosa (T1a) or submucosa (T1b)

T2

Tumor invades into but not beyond the muscularis propria

T3

Tumor invades the adventitia

T4a

Tumor invades adjacent structures that are usually resectable(diaphragm and pericardium)

T4b

Tumor invades unresectable structures

Regional Lymph Nodes (N)

NX

N0

N1

N2

M1

questions.text: A female presents with 35 weeks and 3 days of gestation, AFI = 5 and there is no end-diastolic blood flow. What is the management?

choices.text: Give surfactant and wait till 36 weeks
Do Doppler everyday to check for reversion

questions.solution:
The given case scenario is suggestive of fetal compromise. The management in this patient is immediate termination of pregnancy. Since this pregnancy has crossed 34 weeks, it can be terminated by cesarean section.

Abnormal flow patterns in the umbilical artery:

  • Reduced end-diastolic flow indicates uteroplacental insufficiency (S/D ratio increases)
  • Absent end-diastolic flow suggests fetal compromise, hence the pregnancy is terminated by C-section if >34 weeks.
  • Reverse end-diastolic flow suggests impending doom of death, hence the pregnancy is terminated by C-section if >32 weeks.

questions.text: A 3 year old child is brought to the hospital with complaints of multiple episodes of loose stools and progressive weight loss. She was found to have a mid-upper arm circumference of 10.5 cm. Which of the following is true regarding the management of this child?

choices.text: Administer 10 mL of 50% glucose IV, if unconscious
Continue aggressive hydration, even after dehydration resolves
Use ReSoMal for rehydration 5 mL/kg every 30 min for the first 2 hours

questions.solution:
Progressive weight loss and mid-upper arm circumference of <11.5 cm denote severe acute protein-energy malnutrition (PEM). When accompanied by loose stools, management includes the use of low sodium ORS for rehydration of 5ml/kg every 30 min for the first 2 hours.

Management of fluid/electrolyte status in SAM:

  1. Do not give IV fluids unless the child is in shock.
  2. Give ReSoMal (low-sodium rehydration solution for malnutrition) 5 mL/kg every 30 min for the first 2 hr orally or NG tube.
  3. Then give 5-10 mL/kg in alternate hours for up to 10 hour. The amount depends on stool loss and eagerness to drink. Feed every other alternate hour.
  4. Give ReSoMal after each watery stool as a prevention strategy.
  5. Do not continue aggressive hydration even after dehydration resolves.

Treatment of hypoglycemia in malnutrition:

  • If conscious: 10% glucose (50 mL) orally or 1 teaspoon sugar under the tongue, whichever is the quickest.
  • If unconscious: Immediately give sterile 10% glucose (5 mL/kg) by IV.

Note:

50% glucose is never used in children as it is extremely viscous and concentrated. This could lead to injection site pain, severe thrombophlebitis, and irritation. Also, this can cause osmotic overload in a three-year-old.

Related Pearl: Comparison between low-osmolar oral rehydration solution and ReSoMal

Composition Low-osmolar ORS (mmol/L) ReSoMal (mmol/L)
Glucose  75 125
Sodium  75  45
Potassium  20  40
Chloride  65  70
Citrate  10  7
Magnesium  ---  3
Zinc  --- 0.3
Copper  --- 0.045
Osmolarity (mOsmol/L) 245 300

questions.text: The type of cartilage as shown in the image is present in _________
questions.solution:
The type of cartilage shown in the above image is hyaline cartilage and it is present in bronchi.

Hyaline cartilage is made up of chondrocytes and matrix. The chondrocytes in the deeper matrix are rounded in shape and may appear in a group of eight that originate by the mitotic divisions of a single chondroblast. These groups of cells are called isogenous cell aggregates or cell nests. The important components of the matrix are type II collagen, aggrecan (proteoglycan) and chondronectin (glycoprotein). The matrix which immediately surrounds the chondrocytes is basophilic and is known as the territorial matrix and the matrix which are more distant from the cells appears pale and is known as the interterritorial matrix.

On microscopy, hyaline cartilage can be identified by:

  • Presence of chondrocytes within lacunae.
  • Group of two or more chondrocytes which are known as isogenous cell aggregates or cell nests.
  • Basophilic territorial matrix and pale interterritorial matrix
  • Presence of perichondrium with outer fibrous and the inner cellular layer

Related Pearl: Types of Cartilage

Type of Cartilage Hyaline Cartilage Elastic Cartilage Fibrocartilage
Colour Bluish opalescent Yellow White
Collagen type Type 2 Type 2 Type 1 (mainly) and type 2
Perichondrium Present (except at epiphyses & articular cartilage) Present Absent
Calcification Occurs with old age No calcification Occurs only with bone repair
Cells Chondroblasts & chondrocytes Chondroblasts & chondrocytes Fibroblasts & chondrocytes
Fibres Thin collagen Elastic fibres Thick collagen

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with a phobic disorder. Which of the following defense mechanisms is likely to be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
Displacement is the defense mechanism in phobias. It is the shifting of emotions about one object/individual onto another object/individual.

Related Pearl: Defense mechanisms

Narcissistic-psychotic defenses

Denial: Used to avoid becoming aware of some painful aspects of reality.

  • Eg: I know I do not have cancer.

Distortion: Grossly reshaping the experience of external reality to suit inner needs.

  • Eg: I possess special powers and abilities and am superior to others.

Projection (psychotic): Attributing your own wishes, thoughts, or feelings onto someone else.

  • Eg: I’m sure my wife is cheating on me.

Splitting: External objects are divided into all good or all bad.

  • Eg: The morning staff is perfect, the evening staff is terrible.

 

Immature defenses

Acting out: Behavioral or emotional outburst.

  • Eg: My 10-year-old started getting into trouble right after his mother and I got divorced.

Blocking: Temporary block in thinking.

  • Eg: I have known him for years but can never seem to remember his name.

Hypochondriasis: A defense style in which people say that no one understands their pain.

  • Eg: No one understands the depth of my pain.

Introjection: Features of the external world are taken and made part of the self.

  • Eg: The resident physician dresses like the attending whom he admires.

Passive-aggressive behavior: Aggressive intent is cloaked by a passive method.

  • Eg: Procrastinating at work for not getting the promotion.

Projection (non-psychotic): Unwanted feelings are displaced onto another person.

  • Eg: A man who has been unfaithful to his wife but accuses his wife of cheating on him.

Regression: Return to an earlier stage of development, most immature.

  • Eg: Ever since my divorce, my 5-year-old has begun to wet the bed.

Schizoid fantasy: Tendency to retreat into fantasy in order to resolve inner and outer conflicts.

  • Eg: Adolescents day dreaming on pornographic materials.

Somatization: Psychic derivatives are converted into bodily symptoms.

  • Eg: Just thinking of the exam I get butterflies in my stomach.

 

Neurotic defenses

Externalization: Perceiving one’s personality, impulses, moods and attitudes in the external world.

  • Eg: An argumentative person perceives the doctor as argumentative whilst believing himself to be blameless.

Displacement: Shifting emotions about one object/ individual onto another object/ individual.

  • Eg: Getting angry at your parents because you had a bad day at work.

Inhibition: conscious or unconscious constraint of a process or behavior.

  • Eg: A desire to eat dessert versus the desire to lose weight.

Intellectualization: Excessive use of intellectual processes to avoid affective expression or experience.

  • Eg: It is interesting to note the specific skin lesions which seem to arise as a consequence of my end-stage disease.

Isolation: Separation of an idea from the affect that accompanies it.

  • Eg: As she arrived at the station to identify the body, she appeared to show no emotion.

Rationalization: Rational explanations are used to justify unacceptable attitudes, beliefs, or behaviors.

  • Eg: I did not pass the test because it was harder this year than ever before.

Reaction formation: An unacceptable impulse is transformed into its opposite; results in the formation of character traits.

  • Eg: Listen to him tell his family he was not afraid when I saw him crying.

Repression: An idea or feeling is withheld from consciousness; unconscious forgetting.

  • Eg: I do not remember having had a dog.

Sexualization: Endowing an object or function with sexual significance.

Undoing: Acting out the reverse of unacceptable behavior; consists of an act.

  • Eg: I need to wash my hands whenever I have these thoughts.

Retroflexion: Self-destruction due to rage.

  • Eg: A person cutting his wrist because he is angry with himself.

 

Mature defenses

Altruism: Getting pleasure from giving to others what the individual would have liked to receive.

  • Eg:  A former alcoholic funding a rehabilitation center.

Anticipation: Realistically planning or anticipating future inner discomfort.

  • Eg: Moderate amount of anxiety before surgery.

Asceticism: Gratification derived from renunciation.

Humor: Permits the expression of feelings and thoughts without personal discomfort.

  • Eg: Before execution, firing squad leader offers the man a cigarette. He replies "no thanks I'm trying to quit".

Sublimation: Impulse gratification has been achieved, but the aim or object has been changed from unacceptable to acceptable; allows instincts to be channeled. Most mature of the defenses.

  • Eg: Jack the Ripper becomes a surgeon.

Suppression: Conscious forgetting. The only conscious defense mechanism.

  • Eg: I would rather talk about my operation after the party is over.

questions.text: All of the following are rapidly acting blood pressure control mechanisms except:
questions.solution:
Renin-angiotensin vasoconstrictor mechanism is not a rapidly acting pressure control mechanism, it is an intermediate-acting mechanism.

Regulation of Arterial Blood Pressure:

  • Rapidly acting pressure control mechanism (acting within sec or min)
    • The chemoreceptor reflex.
    • The central nervous system ischemic mechanism.
    • The baroreceptor reflex.
  • Intermediate-acting mechanisms (act after minutes)
    • The capillary fluid shift mechanism.
    • Stress-relaxation of the vasculature.
    • The renin-angiotensin vasoconstrictor mechanism.
  • Long-term mechanisms (after days)
    • Renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS)

Note:

  • Renin-angiotensin vasoconstrictor mechanism is an intermediate-acting mechanism, but water conservation by RAAS is a long-term mechanism in the regulation of BP.
  • Most rapidly acting: Baroreceptor reflex>>Chemoreceptor reflex

questions.text: During thyroidectomy, the given instrument was used to retract the strap muscles. Identify the instrument:
questions.solution:
The above image is that of a Langenbeck retractor. It is used for holding open wounds, as in an open appendicectomy. 

Option B: Dyball retractor is used in major abdominal surgeries to retract deeper parts of the abdominal wall, bladder, or uterus while operating on the rectum and entering the rectovesical or rectouterine pouch. It has a lip at the bottom of the blade to prevent slippage. Care should be taken when it is used to retract the liver as it may damage the liver parenchyma.

Option C: Goligher retractor is a self-retaining retractor used in operations on the sigmoid colon and rectum, such as anterior resection and the upper end of abdominoperineal resection. The retractor is inserted with the side blades to separate the edges of the abdominal wall. The central blade is then inserted to keep the small bowel away from the operation site.

Option D: Travers retractor is a self-retaining retractor used for intermediate-type operations, such as:

  • Herniorrhaphy
  • Groin dissection for varicose veins
  • Femoral embolectomy.

questions.text:
ABG analysis of a patient is shown below. What is the probable underlying acid-base disorder in this patient?

pH- 7.1

pCO2- 16 mmHg

HCO3- - 6 mEq/L

pO2- 78 mmHg

choices.text: Metabolic acidosis with compensatory respiratory alkalosis
Metabolic alkalosis with compensatory respiratory acidosis
Respiratory acidosis with compensatory metabolic alkalosis

questions.solution:
The underlying acid-base disorder in this patient is metabolic acidosis with compensatory respiratory alkalosis.

Interpretation of the ABG:

Step 1: A pH of 7.1 signifies acidosis.

Step 2: Plasma HCO3- is 6 mEq/L, along with a low pH it signifies metabolic acidosis. 

Step 3: pCO2 is 16 mmHg indicating respiratory alkalosis. The decrease in pCO2 along with the decrease in pH suggests that this is a compensatory response.

Step 4: The expected compensatory decrease in pCO2 can be calculated using Winter's formula (Expected PCO2= {[1.5 x HCO3-] +8} ± 2).

Expected PCO2 = {[1.5 x 6] +8} ± 2 = 15 to 19 mmHg

A pCO2 level of 16 mmHg falls within the range given above. Hence, metabolic acidosis is associated with compensatory respiratory alkalosis.

(pCO2 values above or below 15 - 19 mmHg would indicate mixed acid-base disorders)

Alternatively:

The other method to calculate the expected compensation is a 1.2 mmHg decrease in pCO2 for every 1 mmol/L decrease in bicarbonate.

The decrease in bicarbonate is 24 - 6 = 18 mEq/L

Decrease in pCO2 is 18 x 1.2 = 22

Expected pCO2 = 40 - 22 = 18 mmHg (roughly = 16 mmHg since the standard values are approximations)

This method also indicates primary metabolic acidosis with compensatory respiratory alkalosis. However, Winter's formula is more accurate.

Related Pearl: Acid-Base Balance - Normal Values

Component Normal Range Optimal Value
pH 7.35 - 7.45 7.4
HCO3-  22 - 28 mEq/L   24 mEq/L
pCO2 35 - 45 mmHg 40 mmHg 
Anion gap 6 - 12 mEq/L <10 mEq/L
O2 saturation > 95%
pO2 75 - 100 mmHg  

Related Pearl: Expected compensation in acid-base disorders

Primary disorder Expected compensation
Metabolic acidosis

Expected PaCO2 = [1 .5 X HCO3-] + 8 ± 2; or

↓ PaCO2 = 1.25 x ΔHCO3
Metabolic alkalosis Increase in PaCO2 = 0.75 x ΔHCO3-

Respiratory acidosis
Acute

Increase in HCO3- = 0.1 x Δ PaCO2

↓ pH = 0.008 x ΔPaCO2
Chronic

Increase in HCO3- = 0.4 x Δ PaCO2

↓ pH = 0.003 x ΔPaCO2

Respiratory alkalosis

Acute

Decrease in HCO3- = 0.2 x Δ PaCO2

↑ pH = 0.008 x ΔPaCO2

Chronic

Decrease in HCO3- = 0.4 x Δ PaCO2

questions.text: A toddler was brought to the pediatrician with forearm swelling and inconsolable crying. An x-ray revealed the following. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a fracture with a broken cortex on one side and an intact cortex on the other side. This is called a greenstick fracture and is common in children. 

Option A: Torus fracture or buckle fracture occurs due to buckling of the cortex. It most commonly occurs at the transition between metaphysis and diaphysis.

Option B: Nightstick fracture refers to a fracture of the shaft of the ulna.

Option C: Monteggia fracture refers to a fracture of the proximal ulna with an associated radial head dislocation.

questions.text: In an immunocompromised patient, which of the following is the drug of choice for prophylaxis of pneumocystis jirovecii?
questions.solution:
Trimethoprim-Sulfamethoxazole combination (commonly known as cotrimoxazole) is the first-line drug for both prophylaxis and treatment of Pneumocystis jirovecii infections in immunocompromised patients.

Cotrimoxazole acts by causing a sequential block of folate metabolism. CD4+ T cell counts below 200 cells/μL are an indication to start prophylaxis.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man is brought to the casualty with a suspected drug overdose. His sister tells you that he has recently started taking a 'superman drug' after hearing about it from his friends. What drug is she referring to?
questions.solution:
Amphetamines are also known as the superman drug. 

This is because their effects include increased self-confidence and endurance. However, its usage leads to tolerance and dependence.

questions.text: A  patient presented with fever, seizures, and altered sensorium. Gram stain of the CSF is given below. Satellitism was seen on blood agar. Which of the following statements is false about this disease?

choices.text: This is the most serious disease produced by this organism.
The disease is more common in young adults.
The bacilli reach the meninges from the nasopharynx through the bloodstream.
Cefotaxime is the drug of choice

questions.solution:
The given scenario and the image showing gram-negative coccobacilli in the CSF are suggestive of hemophilus meningitis caused by H.influenzae. Hemophilus meningitis is more common in children between 3 months and 3 years of age and not common in young adults. 

Other options:

Option A: Meningitis is the most serious disease caused by H. influenzae. The case fatality rate is 90% if untreated.

Option C: H. influenze is transmitted via respiratory droplets. Thus, it is introduced into the nasopharynx of the contacts of an infected individual. It has to enter the bloodstream to reach the meninges.

Option D: Cefotaxime or ceftazidime are the drugs of choice for the treatment of hemophilus meningitis.

questions.text: A primigravida presents in the 2nd trimester complaining that her slippers do not fit anymore. On examination, her pulse is 88/min and blood pressure is 130/84mm Hg. You note bilateral pitting edema up to the level of ankles. What would you advise her?
questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of physiological edema during pregnancy for which the most appropriate treatment is bed rest.

It occurs due to increased venous pressure of the inferior extremities by the gravid uterus pressing on the common iliac veins.

Features of physiological edema in pregnancy are:

  • Slight degree of ankle edema
  • Usually confined to one leg, more commonly the right leg
  • Not associated with any other features of preeclampsia (like BP>140/90mm Hg, proteinuria)
  • Disappears with rest
  • Other cardiac, renal and hematological pathologies are absent

questions.text: A 5-year-old child was admitted to the hospital with a history of prolapsing rectal mass and painless rectal bleeding. The histopathological image of the mass is as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and the histopathological image showing characteristic cystically dilated crypts and glands are suggestive of a juvenile polyp.

Juvenile polyps are malformations of epithelium and lamina propria commonly located in the rectum. It is seen in children <5 years of age. The typical presentation is painless rectal bleeding. Sometimes there may be a proliferating rectal mass.

The disease may be sporadic or syndromic. 

  • Sporadic juvenile polyp occurs as a single mass and is called retention polyp.
  • Juvenile polyposis syndrome is characterized by multiple hamartomatous polyps, which may be premalignant.

Morphologically, both of these types are indistinguishable.

  • Gross appearance: They appear as pedunculated, smooth reddish lesions, and with cystic spaces.
  • Microscopic appearance: The cysts appear as dilated glands filled with mucin and inflammatory debris.

Note: Complex glandular architecture and the presence of smooth muscle cutting through the lamina propria are seen in Peutz-Jeghers polyps.

questions.text: Which of the following phospholipids is a constituent of the human lung surfactant?
questions.solution:
Dipalmitoyl lecithin/Dipalmitoylphosphatidylcholine (DPPC) is a major component of lung surfactant.

In DPPC, positions 1 & 2 on the glycerol are occupied by palmitate. 

Surfactant is secreted by the type 2 pneumocytes in the alveoli. It reduces surface tension at the air-liquid interface of the alveolus.

Clinical correlate :

  • Respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) in preterm neonates is due to insufficient surfactant production.
  • Lung maturity of the fetus can be assessed by determining the ratio of lecithin to sphingomyelin (L:S ratio) in the amniotic fluid. A ratio of >2 indicates maturity.

Related Pearl: Pulmonary Surfactant Composition

Constituents

Percentage

Phospholipids, mainly dipalmitoylphosphatidylcholine (DPPC)

70% to 80%

Proteins

10%

Neutral lipids

10%

questions.text: In which of the following patients is therapy with an adrenergic-agonist not useful?

choices.text: 50-year-old woman suffering from acute decompensated heart failure
35-year-old man in septic shock with persistent hypotension

questions.solution:
Adrenergic agonists are not useful in the treatment of erectile dysfunction. Adrenergic antagonists (phentolamine) are used locally for vasodilation in erectile dysfunction as PIPE therapy (Phentolamine Induced Penile Erection).

Adrenergic agonists are mainly sympathomimetic due to their action on peripheral vascular or post-synaptic alpha receptors. However, certain adrenergic agonists (like clonidine) act as a sympatholytic due to their predominant action on pre-synaptic α2 receptors which inhibits the release of noradrenaline.

Options A and B: In hypotensive states like shock and acute decompensated heart failure, short-term therapy with parenteral sympathomimetic drugs are indicated in treatment.

Option C: Clonidine is an adrenergic agonist which acts on the pre-synaptic α2 receptor and is used in the treatment of hypertension.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman conceived after being treated for infertility. Her USG scan is given below. What is her diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the twin peak sign which is seen in dichorionic diamniotic twins. This is also known as the lambda sign or delta sign.

In dichorionic twins, the intervening membrane between the twins has 4 layers i.e. 2 chorions and 2 amnions. The placenta protrudes from the base to the space between the 2 amnion layers. This gives rise to the twin peak sign i.e. triangle with the base at placenta and apex in the intervening membrane.

 

Sonographic assessment of dichorionicity is done by observing the following:

  • Number of placental masses - 2
  • Presence of intervening membrane - twin peak or lambda or delta sign
  • Thickness of intervening membranes ≥ 2mm

The best time of delivery of dichorionic diamniotic twins is 38 weeks.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man was brought to you with a history of fever, behavioral changes, and seizures. He is foaming at the mouth and is unable to ingest liquids. The patient was admitted to the ICU, however he died soon after. What is the following finding seen in the patient's post-mortem brain samples known as?
questions.solution:
Fever, neurological symptoms like seizures and altered sensorium, hydrophobia (due to painful muscle contractions during swallowing liquids), and hypersalivation are suggestive of encephalitic rabies. The given image thus represents Negri bodies seen in post-mortem brain samples of patients with rabies. 

Negri bodies are eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions in neurons that are composed of rabies virus proteins and viral RNA. These are commonly observed in the Purkinje cells of the cerebellum and the pyramidal neurons of the hippocampus. Their presence is a characteristic pathologic finding in rabies.

The image below shows Negri bodies:

Related Pearl: Inclusion bodies seen in various conditions/diseases

questions.text: A physician classifies a group of patients based on disease severity as normal, mild, moderate and severe. Which of the following scales of data does this classification system belong to?
questions.solution:
The classification of this disease as normal, mild, moderate and severe belongs to the ordinal scale. This is because this arrangement is not only qualitative but also has a meaningful order with no interval in between.

Related Pearl: Scales of data measurement

Data can be quantitative (numerical values) or qualitative (types, labels).

Quantitative data can be discrete variables or continuous variables.

 

Description

Example

Discrete data

Can take certain values and none in between

Number of cancer patients in a hospital. 

Continuous data

Can take any value usually in between limits or a range. 

Most biomedical data is continuous.

Height, weight, blood pressure, etc.

 

Data always forms one of four scales of measurement – nominal, ordinal, interval, or ratio scales (mnemonic: NOIR):

 

Nominal Scale Data

Ordinal Scale Data

Interval Scale Data

Ratio Scale Data

Example

Male/female; red/green; sub-urban/rural

Students ranked 1st/2nd/3rd in their class. 

A customer feedback survey using terms like very good, good, poor and very poor or the Likert Scale.

Severity of a disease as mild, moderate, severe

 

 Measurements on the celsius scale. Pulse rate; 

Notes

Have no quantitative value.

They have no order or ratio. 

Arranged in a meaningful order.

No size interval is defined

Arranged in a meaningful order with a well defined size interval.

Example: Temperature in Celsius. If temperature in A is 40 deg Celsius and that in B is 20 deg Celsius, then A is 20 deg Celsius hotter than B (taking difference)

Does not have an absolute zero.

For example, Celsius scale has no such thing as “no temperature”. So the value cannot be zero.

Arranged in a meaningful order with a well defined size interval.

Eg: A pulse rate has well defined intervals and is meaningful in comparison. A 100/min pulse is exactly twice of 50 beats/min.

 

Has an absolute zero.

Eg: There can be a value of zero for pulse.

Type

Qualitative

Qualitative

Quantitative

Quantitative

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient was diagnosed with constipation and was started on senna laxatives. After 5 months, the patient came to the hospital with complaints of nausea, vomiting, and abdominal cramping. The colonoscopy of the patient is shown. The diagnosis of this patient is ____________
questions.solution:
The above colonoscopy image depicts a black pigmentation of colonic mucosa that is indicative of melanosis coli. Chronic use of anthraquinone laxatives like senna and cascara sagrada can cause melanosis coil.

As the laxative travels down the intestinal tract, it remains in its inactive form until it reaches the large intestine. Once in the large intestine, the molecules transform into their active form. These active forms of laxative lead to cell damage in the lining of the intestine and death by apoptosis and create a dark pigment, lipofuscin, which eventually lines the large bowel. Eventually, these dead cells are taken up by macrophages. Melanosis coli can occur within only a few months of chronic laxative use. 

Classification of Laxatives

  • Bulk-forming 
    • Dietary fiber: Bran, psyllium/ispaghula, methylcellulose, calcium polycarbophil
  • Stool softener: Docusates (DOSS), Liquid paraffin
  • Stimulant purgatives
    • Diphenylmethanes: bisacodyl, sodium picosulphate
    • Anthraquinones: senna, cascara sagrada
    • 5-HT4 agonist: prucalopride
    • Fixed oil: castor oil
    • Prostaglandin analogue- lubiprostone
  • Osmotic purgatives
    • Magnesium salts: sulfate, hydroxide
    • Sodium salts: sulfate, phosphate
    • Sodium potassium tartrate
    • Lactulose

The main indication of laxatives is the prevention and treatment of acute and chronic constipation.

Docusates are associated with side effects like cramps, abdominal pain, and hepatotoxicity on prolonged usage. Liquid paraffin may be associated with foreign body granulomas, lipid pneumonia, and vitamin deficiencies. Bisacodyl may cause allergic reactions.

questions.text: Which of the following mutations may be found in patients with follicular carcinoma?
questions.solution:
RAS mutations are associated with follicular carcinoma.

It is also associated with acquired muta­tions in the PIK3CA gene (PI­3K/AKT arm of the receptor tyrosine kinase signaling pathway) and the PAX8-PPARG fusion gene.

questions.text: A young patient presents with distension of the abdomen and yellowish discoloration of the eyes for the past 6 months.  After a detailed workup, he is diagnosed with early-stage hepatocellular carcinoma in the left lobe of the liver. The surgeon decides to perform a left hemi-hepatectomy. Which of the following segments has to be removed in the patient?
questions.solution:
In the left hemi-hepatectomy (also called left hepatectomy) the segments marked as II, III, and IV should be removed.

Couinaud classification is the commonly used classification of the liver. It divides the liver is divided into eight segments. Each segment has its own vascular supply, biliary drainage, and lymphatic drainage. Segment I corresponds to the caudate lobe of the liver and segment IV corresponds to the quadrate lobe of the liver. 

The Couinaud's Liver Segments are as follows:

questions.text: A 45-year-old obese man presented to your OPD. His lipid profile showed elevated levels of cholesterol and triglycerides. On examination, you notice palmar xanthomas. What is the drug of choice for his condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of elevated cholesterol and triglycerides along with the presence of palmar xanthomas (pathognomonic sign) is indicative of type III hyperlipoproteinemia. The drugs of choice for this condition are fibrates.

Fibrates are also preferred in patients having severe hypertriglyceridemia (TG >1000 mg/dl) who are at risk for pancreatitis. 

The response to fibrate therapy in Type III hyperlipoproteinemia patients include:

  • Elevated cholesterol and triglyceride levels are dramatically lowered.
  • Tuberoeruptive and palmar xanthomas may regress completely.
  • Angina and intermittent claudication also improve.  

The image below shows palmar xanthoma.

3. Dysbetalipoproteinemia(type III hyperlipoproteinemia) Chylomicrons and VLDL Atherosclerosis and xanthomas
4. Hypertriglyceridemia(type IV hyperlipoproteinemia) VLDL and TG Pancreatitis

questions.text: A forensic team performed a ninhydrin test on some samples obtained from a crime scene. This test can detect which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ninhydrin test is used to detect amino acids.

A purple-colored complex (Ruhemann's purple) indicates a positive reaction. Proline and hydroxyproline form a yellow adduct with ninhydrin. Glutamine and asparagine produce a brown color.

This test is used effectively used at crime scenes to develop and identify latent fingerprints.

questions.text: You are visiting a rural area for a vaccination drive conducted under the Intensified Mission Indradhanush scheme. Which of the following vaccines would you not administer in this vaccination drive?
questions.solution:
Typhoid vaccine is not a part of the Intensified Mission Indradhanush scheme. 

The Intensified Mission Indradhanush scheme has been introduced to ensure full immunization (>90%) by December 2018. It now includes 12 vaccine-preventable diseases (VPDs) (updated from the 7 that Mission Indradhanush focussed on). 4 rounds of immunization are proposed to be held for 7 days each month (from the 7th-13th of each month).

The diseases included in Mission Indradhanush are:

  • TB
  • Polio
  • Hep B
  • Diphtheria
  • Pertussis
  • Tetanus
  • Measles

The diseases included recently in Intensified Mission Indradhanush are:

  • Rotavirus diarrhoea
  • Rubella (as MR vaccine)
  • H. influenzae B diseases (as part of the pentavalent vaccine)
  • Pneumococcal meningitis
  • Japanese Encephalitis

The purpose of Intensified Mission Indradhanush (IMI) is to reach each and every child under 2 years of age and all those pregnant women who have been left uncovered under the routine immunization coverage.

questions.text: A farmer from the sub-Himalayan belt had a thorn prick injury a year back and developed a warty, verrucous growth at the site of prick. A skin biopsy sample was taken and sent for histopathological examination. The characteristic microscopic body as shown in the image was seen. Which of the following could be the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history of a slowly spreading warty, verrucous lesion following a thorn prick injury and the histopathological image showing medlar bodies is suggestive of chromoblastomycosis.

Chromoblastomycosis (chromomycosis) is a subcutaneous mycotic infection that is usually caused by traumatic inoculation. Over months to years, the primary lesion becomes verrucous and wart-like with extension along the draining lymphatics. 

Histologically, the lesions are granulomatous and the dark sclerotic bodies may be seen within leukocytes or giant cells called medlar/copper penny bodies.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl presents with progressive ataxia and symptoms of increased intracranial tension, including headaches and vomiting. MR spectroscopy is performed, as shown below. Based on the findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the magnetic resonance (MR) spectroscopy showing a choline peak is diagnostic of glioma. Creatinine levels are decreased on MR spectroscopy in patients with glioma.

MR spectroscopy is a non-invasive means of obtaining metabolic information. The image below shows a normal MR spectroscopy.

Other options:

Option B: Tuberculoma shows a lipid peak in MR spectroscopy.  

Option C: In Canavan disease, there is a marked increase in N-acetyl aspartate. Its concentration decreases with insults to the brain such as neoplasm, infarct, or abscess. N-acetyl aspartate (NAA) which is the most prominent resonance in a proton spectrum, is accepted as a normal neuronal functional marker.

Option D: Increased choline reflects increased membrane synthesis and/or an increased number of cells, as seen in lymphoma. However, lymphomas of the nervous system are very rare and seen in immunodeficient states like HIV.

questions.text: A 14-year-old patient presents with bilateral proptosis. The biopsy from the region shows this pattern. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and biopsy picture is characteristic of schwannoma.

The biopsy specimen in schwannoma shows hypocellular (Antoni B) and hypercellular areas (Antoni A). Antoni A area has the nuclei of tumor cells aligned in palisading rows. The nuclear-free zones that lie between nuclear palisading are known as Verocay bodies.

The histological section of a schwannoma showing Antoni A, Antoni B and Verocay bodies is given below:

questions.text: A couple with a history of unprotected sexual intercourse requires emergency contraception. Which of the following is not a mechanism by which these drugs act?

choices.text: Preventing the implantation of the fertilized egg

questions.solution:
Emergency contraceptives do not interrupt early pregnancy, once conception has occured. They are used to prevent pregnancy after unprotected intercourse. Hence, they are also called interceptives.

The main action of emergency contraceptives is to make the endometrium unsuitable for implantation. They can also delay or inhibit ovulation, and prevent fertilization of the egg by sperms.

Methods of emergency contraception:

questions.text: In which stage of the demographic cycle is India in currently?
questions.solution:
Currently, India is in stage 3 i.e. late expanding stage of the demographic cycle.

Note: The year 1921 is called the year of the great divide in India. This is because, since 1921, the absolute number of people getting added to the population during each decade has been on the rise. This is the year in which India moved from stage 2 to stage 3 of the demographic cycle.

Related Pearl: Demographic Process and Cycle

Stages of the demographic cycle include:

  • Stage 1 - High stationary 
    • High birth rates and high death rates render the population stationary
    • Narrow demographic gap
  • Stage 2 - Early expanding 
    • The death rate declines and the birth rate remains unchanged
    • The demographic gap starts increasing and becomes maximum
  • Stage 3 - Late expanding
    • Death rate declines further and birth rate falls
    • India is in this stage, currently
    • The demographic gap starts declining
  • Stage 4 - Low stationary 
    • Low birth rate and low death rate renders the population stationary
    • Narrow demographic gap
  • Stage 5 - Declining 
    • The population begins to decline as the birth rate is lower than the death rate
    • The demographic gap is negative

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents with facial oedema that has now progressed to total body swelling involving the face, abdomen, scrotum, and feet. Urinalysis revealed protein 4+ and serum cholesterol was also elevated. What is the initial treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture and investigations are highly suggestive of minimal change nephrotic syndrome and the initial treatment of choice is corticosteroids such as prednisolone.

Minimal change nephrotic syndrome is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome. It is seen in ages 2-6 years with a clinical picture of nephrotic syndrome, that is, heavy proteinuria, oedema, hypoalbuminemia and hyperlipidemia. They may be asymptomatic or can present with peripheral oedema. Renal biopsy is not required for confirmation and treatment can be initiated if the child fits the standard clinical picture of nephrotic syndrome.

They show excellent response to steroid therapy with prednisone or prednisolone. A daily dose of 2mg/kg (max 60mg) for 6 weeks followed by an alternate dose of 1.5mg/kg (max 40mg) for the next 6-8 weeks is recommended.

Alternative drugs used in steroid-dependent patients, frequent relapsers, steroid-resistant patients, and those with severe corticosteroid toxicity are as follows:

  • Cyclophosphamide
  • Calcineurin inhibitors: Cyclosporine and Tacrolimus
  • Mycophenolate
  • Levamisole
  • Rituximab (chimeric monoclonal antibody against CD20)

questions.text: A patient who is under general anaesthesia shows the following finding on the ET CO2 monitor. Which condition can lead to this characteristic waveform on capnography?
questions.solution:
The above capnographic waveform depicts bronchospasm. 

Shark fin appearance - Prolonged phase II, increased α angle, and steeper phase III suggest bronchospasm or airway obstruction.

Related Pearl: Various capnography waveforms:

A- Obstructive airway or bronchospasm
B- Expiratory valve malfunctioning
C- Inspiratory valve malfunction
D- Normal physiological variant seen in pregnant subjects under GA
E- Curare cleft
F- Rebreathing
G- Esophageal intubation
H- Spontaneous breathing
I-Dual capnogram in one lung transplantation patient. The first peak in phase III is from the transplanted normal lung, whereas the second peak is from the native disease lung. A variation of dual capnogram (steeple sign capnogram – dotted line) is seen if there is a leak around the sidestream sensor port at the monitor
J- Malignant hyperthermia
K- Classic ripple effect during the expiratory pause showing cardiogenic oscillations
L- Sudden rise of baseline and end-tidal PCO2 (PETCO2) due to contamination of the sensor with secretions or water vapor.
The gradual rise of baseline and PETCO2 occurs when soda lime is exhausted. 
M -Intermittent mechanical ventilation (IMV) breaths in the midst of spontaneously breathing patient.
N -Cardiopulmonary resuscitation: capnogram showing positive waveforms during each compression. 
O-Capnogram showing rebreathing during inspiration. This is normal in rebreathing circuits such as Mapleson D or Bain circuit.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presented with generalized weakness and lightheadedness for 2 weeks. Blood investigations were notable for decreased hemoglobin, increased indirect bilirubin, and increased LDH. Her peripheral smear showed RBC fragments. Which vitamin deficiency is associated with the above presentation?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a patient with fatigue and decreased hemoglobin, increased indirect bilirubin, and increased LDH is suggestive of hemolytic anemia. It is associated with a deficiency of vitamin E.

The most important function of vitamin E is its chain-breaking antioxidant role. Vitamin E inhibits lipid peroxidation by free radicals, thereby stabilizing cell membranes. Hence, its deficiency can result in erythrocyte membranes being abnormally fragile leading to hemolytic anemia.

Note: Vitamin K deficiency does not cause hemolysis. It causes manifestations of impaired coagulation, such as easy bruisability, mucosal bleeding, etc. However, vitamin K toxicity can cause hemolysis.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman presented with bloody diarrhea, abdominal pain, hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and acute renal failure. She was diagnosed with hemolytic uremic syndrome and treated with plasmapheresis and dialysis. What is false about the infectious causative agent?

choices.text: It does not produce a Shiga like toxin
There is person to person transmission.

questions.solution:
Hemolytic-uremic syndrome (HUS) is caused by enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC) serotype O157:H7. It produces a Shiga like toxin, therefore EHEC is also known as Shiga toxin-producing E. coli (STEC).

Other options:

Option A - Strains of E. coli producing verocytotoxin or Shiga toxin (stx2a-g) can cause diarrheal disease ranging from mild diarrhea to fatal hemorrhagic colitis and HUS. The most common EHEC belongs to serotype O157:H7.

Option C - In EHEC diarrhea, fecal leukocytes are commonly seen (70%) but although it is an infectious condition, fever is not seen. The absence of fever can lead to its misdiagnosis as a non-infectious condition such as intussusception or ischemic bowel disease.

Option D - The disease is transmitted through contaminated feces. Person-to-person transmission can occur if infected persons do not wash their hands after using the toilet or after changing diapers.

Note: Shiga toxin produced by S. dysenteriae is referred to as Stx.

questions.text: Critical limb ischemia is characterized by all except_____
questions.solution:
Critical limb ischemia is characterized by rest pain and/or ulceration and gangrene. Intermittent claudication progresses to rest pain in critical limb ischemia.

Rest pain occurs with the limb at rest and is felt in the foot; it is exacerbated by lying down or elevation of the foot. Characteristically, the pain is worse at night and it may be lessened by hanging the foot out of bed or by sleeping in a chair. The pressure of clothes on the foot usually makes the pain worse.

Ulceration occurs with severe arterial insufficiency and may present as painful erosion between toes or as shallow, non-healing ulcers on the dorsum of the feet, on the shins, and especially around the malleoli. The blackened mummified tissues of frank gangrene are unmistakable and superadded infection often makes the gangrene wet.

questions.text: During a measles epidemic in the community, an eight-and-a-half-month-old child was vaccinated for measles. What is the correct immunisation schedule to be followed for her, regarding measles?

choices.text: The child should be given a second dose after 4 weeks.
The child should be given a second dose as soon as she reaches 9 months of age.
The child should directly be given the second dose of measles at 16 months.
The child should be given the second dose of measles at 12 months of age.

questions.solution:
In this child, the next dose of measles vaccine should be given after 4 weeks.

While the scheduled age of receiving a measles vaccine is 9 months, it can be lowered up to 6 months during a measles epidemic in the community. 

For infants immunized between 6 to 9 months of age, a second dose should be administered as soon as the child reaches the age of 9 months. It is to ensure adequate immunity has developed, provided that 4 weeks have elapsed since the last dose. 

In this child, the first dose was given at the age of 8 and a half months, and there must be a gap of 4 weeks between the two doses. If the child were to be vaccinated as soon as she turns 9 months old, only two weeks would have been elapsed.

Measles Immunization Day is celebrated on the 16th of March every year to create awareness about this deadly disease. There is no specific treatment for measles but there is a vaccine to protect from the disease, which is both safe & cost-effective.

questions.text: Tubuloglomerular feedback is mediated by the sensing of_____

choices.text: Increased Na + concentration in thick ascending loop of Henle
Increased Cl - concentration in thick ascending loop of Henle
Increased Na + concentration in macula densa
Increased Cl- concentration in macula densa

questions.solution:
Tubuloglomerular feedback is mediated by the sensing of increased Na+ concentration in macula densa.

Macula densa are the specialized cells present at the distal end of the thick ascending loop of Henle where it reaches the glomerulus. Distal convoluted tubule starts from macula densa. Macula forms part of the juxtaglomerular apparatus.

While both Na+ and Cl- are delivered to the macula densa cells, it is the increased concentration of Na+ in the cells that increases the Na+-K ATPase activity leading to the feedback.

questions.text: In a patient with anaemia due to chronic renal failure, which of the following is the long-acting derivative of erythropoietin suitable for treatment?
questions.solution:
Darbepoetin alpha is the recombinant derivative of erythropoietin that is long-acting and approved for anaemia due to chronic renal failure. 

Option A: Oprelvekin is an IL-11 analog that stimulates megakaryocyte maturation. 

Option C: Dornase alfa is a recombinant human DNase 1 that is used in cystic fibrosis to reduce the viscosity of mucosal secretions. 

Option D: Filgrastim is a recombinant human G-CSF, indicated in the treatment of severe neutropenia.

questions.text: Puerperal fever is defined as a temperature of _____.
questions.solution:
Puerperal fever is defined as the temperature of 38 °C or higher (100.4 °F) recorded on 2 separate occasions 24 hours apart within the first 10 days following delivery. This excludes the first 24 hours.

In the first 24 hours, a slight rise of temperature is not uncommon and hence the first 24 hours are excluded while defining puerperal pyrexia.

Note: Generally, fever in an adult is defined as an oral temperature of >37.5 °C.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy was brought to the OPD with difficulty in climbing stairs and walking long distances. His parents say that he has received complaints at school due to progressively worsening handwriting. On examination, pes cavus is noted. Investigations revealed scoliosis and hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. Which of the following is incorrect regarding this condition?

choices.text: Expansion of a GAA trinucleotide repeat

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Friedrich's ataxia. It is associated with mutations of genes on chromosome 9q13.

It is an autosomal recessive disease caused by the expansion of a GAA trinucleotide repeat in the gene encoding frataxin. The clinical features are given by the mnemonic FRIEDRICHS:

  • F - Frequent falls (ataxia), foot deformity (pes cavus or overarched foot)
  • R - Recessive
  • I - Iron accumulation in mitochondria
  • E - Eye movements (nystagmus)
  • D - Dorsal column (loss of fine touch, vibration, position)
  • R - Reflexes (deep tendon) lost, with extensor plantar reflex
  • I - Incoordination
  • C - Cerebellar involvement
  • H - Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM)
  • S - Scoliosis (with kyphosis), staggering gait

 

The major cause of death is cardiomyopathy, which is associated with a high incidence of arrhythmias and congestive heart failure.

questions.text: Placental-site trophoblastic tumor arises from _____.
questions.solution:
Placental-site trophoblastic tumor arises from implantation site intermediate trophoblast. As syncytiotrophoblastic cells are generally absent in this site, it is composed mainly of cytotrophoblastic cells.

Patients with placental site trophoblastic tumors present with vaginal bleeding and modestly elevated serum β-hCG levels. Local invasion into the myometrium and lymphatics occurs. Hysterectomy is the preferred treatment.

questions.text: A man complains of bluish-black discoloration of the sclera and pinna for the last 6 months. Since childhood, his urine has turned black on standing, as shown in the image below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of a patient with urine that turns black on standing and blackish discoloration of soft tissues (oochronosis) is characteristic of alkaptonuria. It occurs due to the excretion of homogentisic acid in the urine.

Alkaptonuria is an autosomal recessive condition due to the deficiency of homogentisate oxidase (also called homogentisate 1,2-dioxygenase). The homogentisic acid in these patients is oxidized to benzoquinone acetate and polymerized to form black-colored alkapton bodies, which deposit in soft tissues like cartilage, and this phenomenon is called ochronosis.

In the following images, A shows normal urine and B shows urine from patients with alkaptonuria

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman who is 8 months pregnant, myopic, and diabetic presents to you with sudden painless loss of vision in her right eye. She is a known case of Eales' disease. Her blood pressure is 170/110 mmHg. Which of her conditions is responsible for a fundus finding of retinal detachment with a positive shifting fluid sign?
questions.solution:
Exudative retinal detachment is characterized by positive shifting fluid sign. Among her conditions, toxemia of pregnancy is one of the causes of exudative retinal detachment. 

Exudative retinal detachment occurs due to the presence of subretinal fluid in the absence of tear or traction. It is caused by:

  • Malignant melanoma of the choroid
  • Retinoblastoma
  • Vogt–Koyanagi–Harada (VKH) syndrome
  • Uveal effusion syndrome
  • Posterior scleritis
  • Coat’s disease
  • Malignant hypertension
  • Pregnancy-induced hypertensive retinopathy
  • Sympathetic ophthalmitis

Patients present with sudden and painless diminution of vision, visual field defects and grey reflex (detached retina looks grey). Indirect ophthalmoscopy is the investigation of choice.

The image depicts retinal detachment showing a smooth, detached convex retina with subretinal fluid.

questions.text: A 32-year-old lady presented with dry, itchy eyes, blurred vision, and sensitivity to light. She says there are black dots floating around in her visual field. She denies wearing any spectacles or contact lenses. On fundoscopy, the following image is obtained. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Dry, itchy eyes, blurred vision, sensitivity to light with candle wax dripping on fundus examination points to a diagnosis of sarcoidosis.

Sarcoidosis is a chronic granulomatous multi-system disease. Ocular inflammation occurs in 25–70% of sarcoid patients, which includes uveitis, conjuctival and lacrimal gland involvement. Chronic granulomatous panuveitis may be seen. Anterior uveitis is the most common manifestation.

In anterior uveitis due to sarcoidosis, "mutton fat" keratic precipitates (KPs) and/or small granulomatous KPs with iris nodules (Koeppe and/or Busacca) are seen. Trabecular meshwork (TM) nodules and/or tent-shaped peripheral anterior synechiae (PAS) is also seen. 

In intermediate uveitis, vitreous cells with snowbanking and snowball opacities/string of pearl appearance are seen. Posterior uveitis presents with candle-wax dripping (thick venous sheathing and periphlebitis), pre-retinal nodules (Lander’s sign), choroidal granulomata and sarcoid infiltration. Other ocular features seen are interstitial keratitis and band-shaped keratopathy. Steroids are the mainstay of treatment in sarcoidosis.

questions.text: A 48-year-old obese female presents with skin changes in her axilla and neck as shown in the image. Which of the following tumors is not associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture is suggestive of acanthosis nigricans. It is not associated with thymoma.

Acanthosis nigricans is a disorder characterized by gray-black patches of thickened, hyperkeratotic skin with a velvety appearance. The causal mechanism is immunologic due to secretion of epidermal growth factor.

Acanthosis nigricans is commonly associated with:

  • Gastric carcinoma
  • Lung carcinoma
  • Gynecological cancers
  • Breast carcinoma
  • Bladder carcinoma
  • Gallbladder and bile-duct carcinoma
  • Acromegaly and gigantism
  • Dermatomyositis
  • Diabetes
  • Hashimoto thyroiditis
  • Lupus erythematosus
  • Phenylketonuria
  • Polycystic ovary syndrome
  • Systemic sclerosis
  • Wilson syndrome

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is Gelle's test negative?
questions.solution:
Gelle’s test is negative when the ossicular chain is fixed as in cases of otosclerosis. 

Gelle’s test is a test of bone conduction and examines the effect of increased air pressure in the ear canal on hearing. In normal individuals, due to the increased intralabrynthine pressure applied by the Seigel's speculum, there is immobility of the basilar membrane, as the tympanic membrane and the ossicles are pushed inwards (medially). This results in decreased hearing. But, in diseased individuals, where the ossicular chain and the tympanic membrane are fixed or disconnected, no change in hearing is observed. 

Gelle’s test is positive in normal persons and in those with sensorineural hearing loss.

Note: This test was commonly used for the diagnosis of otosclerosis, but has since been replaced by tympanometry.

questions.text: A 29-year-old African American man receives primaquine chemoprophylaxis before traveling for a business trip. Four days later, he presents with jaundice and dark urine. Laboratory investigations show anemia, reticulocytosis, and unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. The peripheral blood smear shows the presence of Heinz bodies. What is the most likely mode of inheritance of the given clinical condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history suggestive of hemolysis after the antimalarial (primaquine) and Heinz bodies on PBF, points to a diagnosis of G6PD deficiency (Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency). It is inherited as an X-linked recessive trait.

G6PD is an enzyme belonging to the hexose monophosphate shunt (HMP) pathway. Deficiency of enzymes of this pathway causes hemolysis as the protective ability of RBCs from oxidative stress is impaired.

The image given below shows the Heinz bodies seen on peripheral smear.

questions.text: An autopsy was done on a burn victim. Which of the following is a reliable indicator that the victim was alive while the fire was in progress?

choices.text: Vital reaction in the burned area
Redness of the exposed skin surface

questions.solution:
Elevated levels of carbon monoxide in the circulating blood and carbon particles in the air passages and lungs are reliable indicators suggesting that the victim was alive while the fire was in progress.

The carbon monoxide concentration in blood depends on various factors like the concentration of carbon monoxide in the air, blood hemoglobin level, duration of exposure, etc. The presence of carbon particles and elevated Carboxy hemoglobin levels are absolute proof that the victim was alive when the fire occurred. Though there is no definite level that confirms the presence or absence of carboxyhemoglobin in the blood, a level of 10% is needed to confirm unless the person is a heavy smoker.

questions.text: A 9-year-old girl was referred to the OPD with a chronic history of early satiety and recurrent non-bilious vomiting after heavy meals. Barium meal revealed a diffusely narrowed second portion of the duodenum, suggesting extrinsic compression. Which of the following statements is false regarding the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: It is associated with failure of complete rotation of the ventral bud
Can be associated with classic double bubble sign on radiograph
Duodenoduodenostomy is the treatment of choice
MRCP is the gold standard investigation

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of annular pancreas, which is a type of developmental anomaly leading to duodenal compression. Laparotomy with a thorough gross examination of the duodenum and the head of the pancreas is the gold standard test for an annular pancreas, not an MRCP.

The annular pancreas is due to result of the failure of the complete rotation of the ventral pancreatic bud. During development, a ring of pancreatic tissue surrounds the second or third part of the duodenum.

It is most often seen in association with congenital duodenal atresia and is, therefore, more prevalent in children with Down’s syndrome.

Duodenal obstruction typically causes non-projectile, non-bilious vomiting in neonates. 

Plain abdominal radiographs may demonstrate the classic double bubble sign. But it is non-specific for the annular pancreas. Despite many advances in diagnostic techniques such as CT scan, endoscopic ultrasound (EUS), MRCP, and ERCP, the gold standard test for diagnosing AP remains to be laparotomy. It involves a thorough gross examination of the duodenum and the head of the pancreas.

The treatment for an annular pancreas is a duodenal bypass procedure (duodenoduodenostomy).

questions.text: A 65-year-old HIV-positive man presented with fever and breathlessness for 2 weeks. Imaging shows dense infiltration in the lower lobe and the lung biopsy showed the following finding. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a cytomegalic pneumocyte containing characteristic intranuclear basophilic inclusion surrounded by a clear halo known as owl’s eye appearance. Along with the given clinical scenario, it is suggestive of cytomegalovirus (CMV) pneumonia. 

CMV is a β-group herpesvirus. It causes the following conditions:

  • Immunocompetent individuals - asymptomatic or mononucleosis-like infection  
  • Neonates - devastating systemic infections
  • Immunosuppressed individuals - serious, life-threatening, disseminated CMV infections of the lungs (pneumonitis) and gastrointestinal tract (colitis)

Option A: Small-cell carcinoma has small cells with scant cytoplasm, salt-and-pepper chromatin with inconspicuous nucleoli.

Option C: In cryptococcal infection, encapsulated yeasts are seen on direct microscopy. 

Option D: Tuberculosis is associated with well-defined epithelioid granuloma.

questions.text: A mother brought her a 6-year-old child with watery nasal discharge, nasal obstruction, frequent sneezing and itching in the nose. She also adds that the symptoms occur during the winter season and there is a history of asthma in the family. Which of the following is not associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a child with watery nasal discharge, frequent sneezing, itching of the nose, and seasonal variation is suggestive of allergic rhinitis, and hypertrophy of turbinates is seen, not atrophy.

Other features of allergic rhinitis:

Option A: Dennie-Morgan lines - transverse skin creases in the infraorbital area.

 

Option B: Allergic salute - is a transverse nasal crease that appears as a black line across the middle of the dorsum of the nose due to constant upward rubbing of nose simulating a salute.

 

Option D: Serous otitis media occurs as a result of eustachian tube blockage.

questions.text: A 15-year-old male patient came to the OPD with cervical lymph node enlargement. The biopsy was examined, which showed a variant of the Reed-Sternberg cell given in the image. Which of the following types of Hodgkin's lymphoma frequently has this cell in its histology?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the lymphohistiocytic variant (L&H) of Reed–Sternberg (RS) cell. It is seen frequently in lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin's lymphoma.

The cell has the following features:

  • Polypoid nuclei
  • Inconspicuous nucleoli
  • Moderately abundant cytoplasm  

As it resembles popcorn in its morphology it is also termed popcorn cell.

Note: A unique paraneoplastic syndrome associated with Hodgkin's lymphoma is the occurrence of pain in the affected lymph nodes during alcohol consumption. This has been attributed to the enlargement of the affected lymph nodes following alcohol consumption, which stretches the capsule of the lymph node and produces pain.

Related Pearl: Important Features of the Different Types of Hodgkin's Lymphoma (HL)

Classic subtypes

  • Nodular sclerosis 
  • Mixed cellularity 
  • Lymphocyte-rich
  • Lymphocyte depletion

Non-Classical subtype

  • Lymphocyte predominant

Note: Mixed cellularity is most commonly associated with HIV due to its high incidence. 

Related Pearl: Variants of Reed Sternberg Cells

Variant Reed–Sternberg cells and the corresponding subtype of Hodgkin's Lymphoma

  • Lacunar Variant: Nodular Sclerosis
  • Mononuclear variant: Mixed cellularity and Lymphocyte rich 
  • Pleomorphic/Necrotic/Mummified Variant: Lymphocyte depleted 
  • L&H/Lymphohistiocytic/Popcorn Variant: Lymphocyte predominant

questions.text: A prison inmate who was in long-term solitary confinement is being subjected to a neuropsychiatric evaluation. He is asked what the colour of the sky is, and he answers that it is green. What is this symptom called?
questions.solution:
When the person gives a wrong answer to a question, but it is very similar to the actual answer, it is called vorbeireden, which means to give 'approximate answers'. 

Here, the person answered 'green' for the colour of the sky. The content of the reply shows that they have understood the nature of the question, but responded wrongly or approximately by talking about an associated topic.

Vorbeireden is a feature of Ganser syndrome (hysterical pseudodementia), commonly found in prison inmates.

Option A: Neologism refers to making new words that do not exist and using them meaninglessly, as seen in schizophrenia. e.g., "The world is not 'gooder' for people like me". 

Option B: Verbigeration is the meaningless and stereotyped repetition of words or phrases, seen in schizophrenia. e.g., "I want to go home go home go home".

Option D: Circumstantiality is the inclusion of irrelevant details and talking in a roundabout manner, but the patient's thought ultimately reaches the answer.

Controversial : The classification of OCD as a certain form of thought is debatable based on the resource. Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry (11th Edition) lists it under disorders of content of thought, whilst Fish's Clinical Psychopathology (4th Edition) mentions it under disorders of possession of thought. Hence, the answer depends on the book referred by the examiner while framing the question.

Related Pearl: Classification of disorders of thought

questions.text: A 43-year-old factory worker presents to you with nasal obstruction, cheek swelling, and diplopia. The ENT resident suspects maxillary carcinoma and uses the following image to classify the same. Which one of the following classification systems are used?
questions.solution:
Ledermann’s classification is used to classify maxillary carcinoma in this case.

It uses two horizontal lines of Sebileau; one passing through the floors of orbits and the other through floors of antra.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man presents with dull aching epigastric pain. He gives a history of acute abdominal pain following a binge of alcohol 5 weeks back which was managed conservatively. On examination, he appears icteric and a firm mass was palpable in the epigastrium. His CT scan is given below.  Which of the following statements is false about his condition?

choices.text: Cyst wall is lined by squamous epithelium.
Splenic artery is the most common artery involved.

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with a history of acute pancreatitis, epigastric mass, and the CT image showing a cyst is suggestive of pancreatic pseudocyst. The capsule of the cyst is composed of collagen and granulation tissue, and it is not lined by epithelium. Hence, it is called a pseudocyst.

Pseudocysts are post-inflammatory cysts that arise following an attack of mild acute pancreatitis. Formation of a pseudocyst requires 4 weeks or more from the onset of acute pancreatitis. They are also the most common complication of chronic pancreatitis.

Pseudocysts are usually solitary and most commonly seen in the lesser omental sac. The most common artery involved is the splenic artery.

 Complications of pancreatic pseudocyst include:

  • Abscess
  • Systemic sepsis
  • GI bleeding
  • Fistula formation
  • Peritonitis
  • Obstructive jaundice
  • Bowel obstruction
  • Hemorrhage into the cyst
  • Hemoperitoneum

Pancreatic pseudo­cysts can be distinguished from cystic neoplasms by having high amylase levels and absence of mucin and low serum carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) levels.

questions.text: Thiazide diuretics are not used in the treatment of which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Thiazide diuretics are not used in the treatment of hyperlipidemia. They result in an increase in the levels of LDL, total cholesterol, and triglycerides.

Option A: Thiazide reduces Ca2+ excretion and is used in the treatment of idiopathic hypercalciuria with nephrocalcinosis.

Option C: They are also used in the treatment of edema associated with CHF, hepatic cirrhosis, and nephrotic syndrome.

Option D: Thiazides are the mainstay for the treatment of nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. They reduce the kidney's ability to excrete free water. They increase proximal tubular water absorption and block the ability of DCT to form dilute urine.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presented with backache. Urine examination revealed nephrotic range proteinuria with Bence-Jones proteins. Laboratory reports showed hypercalcemia. Histopathological examination of the bone marrow aspirate showed the findings as given below. The findings seen on histopathology are due to the accumulation of:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the histopathological image showing Russell bodies are suggestive of multiple myeloma. These are globular, eosinophilic intracellular accumulations of immunoglobulins.

Related Pearl: Pathological Cells/Bodies in Multiple Myeloma

  • Dutcher bodies - pale-staining, PAS-positive intranuclear inclusions within plasma cells containing Ig, which are more common in IgA myeloma (Image below). 

Russell bodies - They are globular intracellular accumulations of immunoglobulins (Ig). Russell bodies are distended endoplasmic reticulum. Plasma cells filled with multiple Russell bodies are called Mott cells.

  • Flame cells - Plasma cells with fiery red cytoplasm due to vermillion-staining, glycogen-rich IgA in cytoplasmic projections

questions.text: A 43-year-old man presented with complaints tracing back a year ago to a traumatic work-related event involving mutilation of his right-hand fingers. He reported having flashbacks and nightmares of the event, inability to perform everyday tasks and a depressive mood. No symptomatology was evident before the event to him or his social milieu. Which of the following is a bad prognostic sign of this disorder?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). Gradual onset of symptoms is a bad prognostic sign of PTSD.

A good prognosis is predicted by:

  • Rapid onset of the symptoms
  • Short duration of the symptoms (less than 6 months)
  • Good premorbid functioning
  • Strong social supports.
  • Absence of other psychiatric, medical, or substance-related disorders.

In general, the very young and the very old have more difficulty with traumatic events than those in midlife.

  • Young children have inadequate coping mechanisms.
  • Older persons are likely to have more rigid coping mechanisms and less able to muster a flexible approach to dealing with the effects of trauma.

questions.text: A patient newly diagnosed with HIV is found to have a CD4+ count of 78cells/µL. Which of the following is not a function of these cells?
questions.solution:
CD4+ is a marker of T helper and memory cells. They do not produce immunoglobulins.

CD4+ T cells are activated when an antigen-presenting cell expressing MHC-II binds to them. The activated CD4+ T cell differentiates into T helper (TH) cells and regulatory T cells. The TH cells are further differentiated into TH1, TH2 and TH17 cells. Helper T cells have the following functions: 

  • Activation and proliferation of cytotoxic T cells
  • Regulation of monocyte-macrophage system
  • Activation of B cell to produce plasma cells
  • Production of interleukins 

Memory cells (Tm) have both CD4+ and CD8+ markers. They provide anamestic immune response and are thus responsible for immunogenic memory. 

Immunoglobulins are produced by the plasma cells.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman diagnosed with Ménière’s disease presented with complaints of sudden onset dizziness and sensation of surroundings swirling. Which of the following drugs cannot be used as a vestibular sedative to treat this condition?
questions.solution:
Among the given drugs, Loratadine is not a vestibular sedative.

Loratadine is a second generation antihistamine which lacks CNS depressant effects. It is used for allergic rhinitis, chronic idiopathic urticaria, and exercise-induced bronchospasm prophylaxis.

The first line of treatment of an acute episode of Ménière’s is symptomatic and hence vestibular sedatives are the mainstay in the treatment. These are

  • Dimenhydrinate
  • Prochlorperazine
  • Promethazine
  • Rarely- diazepam and atropine

questions.text: Which of the following ascending pathways enters the cerebellum through the peduncle highlighted in green in the image?
questions.solution:
The peduncle highlighted in the image is the superior cerebellar peduncle. The anterior spinocerebellar tract enters the cerebellum through it and terminates in both sides of the cerebellum. 

Dorsal spinocerebellar tract enters the cerebellum through the inferior cerebellar peduncle and terminates on the same side as its origin.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy was brought by his parents with concern about being increasingly clumsy for the past 6 months. On examination, there is leukocoria with an absence of the red reflex in the left eye. As further workup reveals a tumor, the eye is enucleated and the microscopic appearance is as shown in the image. Molecular analysis of the tumor indicates loss of cell cycle control in the tumor cells. Where is the responsible gene located?
questions.solution:
The histology showing Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes and clinical history of white reflex point towards a diagnosis of retinoblastoma. Retinoblastoma is due to mutation in Rb gene located on chromosome 13q14.

Retinoblastoma was first cancer known to be directly associated with a genetic abnormality.

 The HPE image below shows Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes, the clustering of small blue cuboidal or short columnar cells around a central lumen.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about giant cell arteritis?

choices.text: May lead to ischemic optic neuropathy

questions.solution:
Giant cell arteritis is common in older women (>50 years of age).

Giant cell arteritis is an inflammatory vasculitis of the large vessels, commonly seen in females over 50 years of age. It usually involves the temporal artery.

It is characterized by fever, anemia, and headache. Depending on the artery involved, the patient may have tenderness over the affected artery, scalp pain, tongue and jaw claudication. Untreated patients may develop ischemic optic neuropathy.

Laboratory investigations reveal elevated ESR and normochromic normocytic anemia. It shows good response to glucocorticoid therapy.

questions.text: A middle-aged obese man has presented to the OPD with acute pain around his left first metatarsophalangeal joint. He has a history of similar episodes in the past. X-ray is given below. Which drug is commonly used as initial treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and the X-ray showing Martel's sign point towards a diagnosis of acute on chronic presentation of gout. Indomethacin is commonly used in the initial treatment of gout.

In addition to inhibiting prostaglandin synthesis, indomethacin and other NSAIDs also inhibit urate crystal phagocytosis.

Option A - Aspirin is not used because it causes renal retention of uric acid at low doses. It is uricosuric only at higher doses that are poorly tolerated.

Option C - Allopurinol is used for prophylaxis of gout.

Option D - NSAIDs are selected over colchicine because of troublesome diarrhea associated with colchicine.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man was rushed to the ER with impaired consciousness following a hunger strike for a day. His wife reported, he had a head injury 1 month back and since then had complaints of polyuria. On examination, he was found to be severely dehydrated and MRI brain showed an absence of the characteristic bright spot in the pituitary.  Which of the following is the drug of choice for his condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of polyuria following a head injury and an absence of a pituitary bright spot on the MRI brain is suggestive of central diabetes insipidus. The drug of choice for this condition is desmopressin, a V2 receptor agonist.

Mechanism of action of desmopressin is: It stimulates the V2 receptors on the basolateral membrane of the principal cells in the collecting tubules. This increases the insertion of water channels (aquaporin 2) into the apical membrane. This leads to increased water reabsorption in the collecting ducts. Activation of V2 receptors also increase the permeability of urea.

Option B: Amiloride is a potassium-sparing diuretic. It is indicated for lithium-induced nephrogenic diabetes insipidus.

Option C: Thiazides paradoxically exert an antidiuretic effect in DI but are not the drugs of choice. They are generally used in nephrogenic DI.

Option D: Triamterene is also a potassium-sparing diuretic that can be used to treat nephrogenic DI.

Note: Patients with DI usually do not develop overt signs of dehydration due to increased intake of water to compensate for polyuria. But when water intake is impaired they can present with dehydration.

Related Pearl: Types of vasopressin receptors and their functions
