questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents to the OPD with complaints of blood in her urine. She informs you that this happens every month for 1 week and stops on its own. She underwent a C-section 1 year ago and has no history of incontinence. During clinical examination, a catheter is inserted into the bladder, and the following finding is seen. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the catheter emerging from the cervical os. This, along with the history of cyclical hematuria, is suggestive of Youssef syndrome seen in a case of vesicouterine fistula.

Vesicouterine fistulas can develop after cesarean section, uterine rupture, and placenta accreta. Most cases present weeks to years later.

Vesicouterine fistulas can present with cyclical hematuria, urinary incontinence or complete continence, menstrual abnormalities, and urinary tract infections. Youssef syndrome is seen in cases of vesicouterine fistulas, and it is associated with a classic triad:

  • Amenorrhea
  • Cyclical hematuria - also called menouria: Menstrual blood trickles into the bladder through the fistula, causing hematuria
  • Urinary continence (there is no vaginal leakage of urine)

Hysteroscopy and cystoscopy are gold-standard investigations. 

Vesicouterine fistulas are treated as follows: 

  • Prolonged bladder catheterization - leads to spontaneous closure
  • Surgical repair via abdominal route

questions.text: You are the intern posted in the labor room and are tasked with calculating the gestational maturity of the infants delivered. As per the expanded New Ballard scoring, what will be the lowest and highest scores you can obtain?
questions.solution:
The lowest score on the expanded New Ballard Score is -10, which corresponds to 20 weeks gestational age, and the highest score is 50, which corresponds to 44 weeks gestational age.

An increase in the score by 5 points corresponds to an increase of 2 weeks gestational age.

questions.text: Multiple inmates at a prison are suspected to have epidemic typhus following an arthropod infestation. Which of the following vectors is implicated in the spread of this disease?
questions.solution:
Louse (image B), Pediculus humanus corporis, transmits epidemic typhus. 

Gaol fever/ Jail fever/ epidemic typhus is caused by Rickettsia prowazekii.

Related Pearl: Lice

  • There are 3 kinds of lice. They are:
    • Head lice (Pediculus capitis)
    • Body lice (Pediculus corporis)
    • Crab louse (pubic louse – Phthirus pubis).
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a pair of antennae, three pairs of legs attached to the thorax, and a segmented abdomen.
  • The stages in their life cycle are eggs (nits), larva (nymph), and the adult, which live for 30 to 50 days.
  • They are spread by direct or indirect contact.
  • They are vectors for epidemic typhus, relapsing fever, trench fever, and pediculosis.
  • Insecticidal control of lice is mainly by malathion in the form of lotion or powder.
  • There are reports of resistance to DDT and HCH.
  • Personal hygiene is of utmost importance to prevent infestation.

questions.text: A 24-year-old primigravida delivers a preterm baby at 33 weeks of gestation with a birth weight of 2 kg. She is advised to hold her child as shown below.  Which of the following statements about this method is false?

choices.text: Safety and thermal protection is equivalent to incubators
Reduces severe morbidity in the newborns
Should be performed only by the mother

questions.solution:
Kangaroo Mother Care (KMC) can be carried out by the mother or any other caregiver.

KMC was introduced for the prevention of neonatal hypothermia in low birth weight/ premature newborns. It has 4 components—

  • Skin-to-skin positioning of the newborn on the mother’s chest.
  • Adequate nutrition through breastfeeding.
  • Early discharge and ambulatory care.
  • Support for mother and family for child care.

Evidence shows that-

  • It is as good as incubators, in terms of safety and thermal protection (measured by mortality)
  • Reduces severe morbidity by way of facilitating breastfeeding
  • Humanization of neonatal care
  • Promoted bonding between mother and child

Eligibility criteria for KMC:

It is indicated for all hemodynamically stable low birth weight babies. Short sessions of KMC can be initiated in babies on medical treatment like IV fluids or oxygen therapy. Initiation of KMC can vary with the birth weight of the baby.

  • Birth weight <1200 g - It may take days to weeks for initiation of KMC
  • Birth weight =1200-1800 g - Only a few days may be taken before KMC initiation
  • Birth weight >1800 g - KMC can be initiated immediately after birth

All mothers without any serious illness can provide KMC.

Positioning for KMC: The baby is placed between the mother's breast in an upright position. The hips are abducted and flexed in the frog position and the arms are also flexed. The abdomen of the baby should be at the level of the mother's epigastrium. In this position, the mother's breathing would stimulate the baby and prevent the development of apnea.

The duration of KMC should be gradually increased from short sessions of more than one hour to 24 hours a day.

KMC is not necessary once the baby attains 2500 g of weight or 37 weeks of gestation.

Note: 

Incubatory care, feeding via nasal catheter, and prevention of infection are part of intensive care for low birthweight babies.

World Kangaroo Care Awareness Day is a global healthcare awareness event observed annually on 15th of May with an intention of spreading the benefits. Studies show that infants who underwent KMC had a low death count during the first-year follow-up. In addition, they also had lower rates of school absenteeism, hyperactivity, aggression, and socio-deviant behaviour among young adults than the control group after 20 years of follow-up.

questions.text:
A 12-year-old boy is brought with a history of fever and swelling over the right leg. His X-ray and lab investigations are given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?

TLC - 20,000 cells/cu.mm

ESR - 70 mm/hr

CRP - 30 mg/L

Immunohistochemical staining with MIC-2 - Positive
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis is Ewing's sarcoma.

The clinical vignette of a 12-year-old boy presenting with fever, swelling over the right leg, an elevated leukocyte count, ESR and CRP, MIC-2 staining being positive and the X-ray showing onion skin appearance are all suggestive of Ewing's sarcoma.

It is a highly malignant tumour that frequently affects males between 10 and 20 years of age. It usually affects the diaphysis of long bones like the femur and tibia. The femur is the most commonly affected, followed by the tibia, humerus and fibula, but overall the pelvis accounts for the majority of cases.

Pain is the earliest symptom, followed by swelling and a low-grade fever. Serologically, the ESR and WCC may be elevated and haemoglobin may be reduced.

An x-ray shows an aggressive, poorly defined osteolytic lesion with cortical destruction and periosteal reaction. A distinct ‘onion-skin’ appearance is observed due to the destruction of the cortex and new bone formation in layers.

Histologically, Ewing’s sarcoma is composed of primitive, undifferentiated, small, round blue cells with large nuclei and scant cytoplasm that bears no resemblance to normal tissue. The characteristic translocation between chromosomes 11 and 22 results in a fusion gene, EWSR1-FL11, which is present in 90% of cases. The presence of the translocation may be supported by means of fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH).

Immunohistochemical staining for MIC-2 is specific for Ewing’s sarcoma.

The most common sites of metastasis include lungs, bones and lymph nodes. Bone marrow involvement is a unique feature of Ewing’s sarcoma.

Preoperative chemotherapy with vincristine, ifosfamide, doxorubicin and etoposide results in extensive tumour necrosis and shrinkage. Wide excision may be combined with adjuvant radiotherapy if surgical margins are poor. Definitive radiotherapy rather than surgical excision may be advocated if it is non-resectable or metastasis has occurred. It is a radio-sensitive tumour.

Indicators of a favourable prognosis include younger age, involvement of distal appendicular sites, small tumour volume, normal ESR and greater chemotherapy response.

questions.text: In the ophthalmology practical examination, the external examiner asks you to identify the given object. Choose the correct answer.

choices.text: Modified C loop posterior chamber IOL
Singh and Worst's iris claw lens

questions.solution:
The image depicts Kelman multiflex type of anterior chamber intraocular lens (ACIOL). It is the most commonly used ACIOL.

Anterior chamber IOLs lie entirely in front of the iris and are supported in the angle of the anterior chamber. These are associated with a higher incidence of bullous keratopathy. Thus, they are currently used only for correction of aphakia in cases where posterior chamber IOLs cannot be used (eg: rupture of posterior capsule).

questions.text: A 38-year-old man presented with chronic diarrhea, weight loss, and joint pains. A duodenal biopsy was done. Which of the following drug is used in the maintenance phase of treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
The above image shows PAS-positive foamy macrophages present in the lamina propria. This along with the given features suggests Whipple's disease. Cotrimoxazole is used in the maintenance phase of the treatment of Whipple's disease.

Treatment of Whipple's disease:

  • Induction phase- ceftriaxone or meropenem or penicillin G + streptomycin - 2 weeks
  • Maintenance phase- trimethoprim / sulfamethoxazole (TMP/SMX) for 1 year. It has high CNS penetration so it is used in maintenance to prevent relapse.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with stage 5 chronic kidney disease is planned for hemodialysis. Which of the following is incorrect regarding the vascular access for this procedure?

choices.text: Tunneled catheters are associated with lower infection rates
Access of choice is radiocephalic arteriovenous fistula
Most common complication of arteriovenous grafts is infection
Fistulas have higher long term patency rates

questions.solution:
The most common complication of arteriovenous (AV) grafts is stenosis, not infections.

In order to perform hemodialysis, vascular or hemodialysis access must first be established. The preferred site is the forearm. The following types of vascular access may be used for hemodialysis:

  • AV fistulas:
    • Fistula refers to the anastomosis of an artery and an adequately large vein (either side-to-side or end-to-side).
    • This causes arterialization of the vein, thereby causing venous wall thickening and increasing venous diameter.
    • Fistulas need 4-6 weeks to mature before they can be used. 
    • The access of choice is radiocephalic AV fistula (Brescia-Cimino fistula).
    • Fistulas have higher long-term patency rates than grafts.
    • Thrombosis is a common complication.

The following image depicts a radiocephalic fistula.

  • AV grafts:
    • The artery and vein are connected by a prosthetic graft such as PTFE (polytetrafluoroethylene).
    • The advantage is that it can be performed with smaller veins.
    • Complications include stenosis (most common), due to intimal hyperplasia at anastomosis between graft and vein, and infections.
  • Central venous catheter:
    • Tunneled catheters are used for long-term IV access. As they tunnel through the skin before entering the vein, they have a lower risk of infection.

Related Pearl: Hemodialysis vs Peritoneal dialysis

Difference between Hemodialysis and Peritoneal dialysis

Hemodialysis Peritoneal dialysis

Better clearance Good clearance
Short time for treatment Longer time may be required
Principle:

Solute removal through a semi-permeable membrane.

Principle:

Solute removal through a peritoneal membrane
Must be done in hospital Can be done at home
Complications:
  • Hypotension
  • Disequilibrium syndrome
  • Muscle cramps
  • Anaphylaxis reaction

Complications :

  • Peritonitis
  • Catheter-associated non-peritoneal infections
  • Weight gain
  • Metabolic disturbances
  • Residual uremia

questions.text: Identify the structure marked in the CT scan shown below:
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the given CT thorax image is the superior vena cava.

The image below depicts all the major structures labelled in the CT thorax image:

questions.text: An elderly man is brought to the hospital with confusion and drowsiness. His son says that he has been urinating more frequently than normal and eating very little over the past 1 week. Capillary blood glucose is 800 mg/dl.  Which of the following would not be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of hyperglycemic hyperosmolar state (HHS). Kussmaul's breathing is not a feature of HHS.

HHS is commonly seen in older adults suffering from type 2 diabetes mellitus. Patients can present with the following features:

  • Polyuria
  • Polydipsia
  • Lethargy 
  • Altered sensorium, coma
  • Seizures
  • Severe dehydration

The following lab values are seen: 

  • Blood glucose of 600-1200 mg/dl
  • Serum osmolality > 350 mOsm/L
  • Prerenal azotemia due to dehydration
  • Pseudohyponatremia may be seen due to hyperglycemia
  • Normal pH and ketones

The mainstay of management is fluid replacement, IV regular insulin, along with potassium replacement.

Heparin can be given prophylactically as volume contraction can increase the risk of venous thrombosis.

questions.text: A patient with hereditary spherocytosis is set to undergo a splenectomy. During the procedure, which of the following sites is the splenic artery ligated at?
questions.solution:
The splenorenal ligament contains the splenic artery. So during splenectomy, it is ligated at the splenorenal ligament.

Splenic ligament Attachments Contents
Gastrosplenic ligament Greater curvature of the stomach to the upper pole of the spleen

Short gastric vessels

Left gastroepiploic vessels
Phrenicosplenic ligament Posterior abdominal wall to the upper pole of the spleen -
Splenorenal (lienorenal) ligament Hilum of the spleen to the anterior surface of the left kidney

Tail of pancreas

Splenic artery and vein

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with sudden onset chest pain radiating to the back between the scapulae. The CT of this patient is given below. What is the major risk factor for developing this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the CT finding of a second column of blood after an intimal tear is the classic presentation of an aortic dissection. The major risk factor for aortic dissection is hypertension.

Dissection occurs when blood enters into the media to form a blood-filled channel between the laminar planes of the media. It usually occurs due to a tear in the intima which allows blood in the lumen to flow into the media. It may also occur due to the rupture of vasa vasorum.

It occurs due to:

  • Hypertension
  • Connective tissue defects like Marfan syndrome 
  • Iatrogenic trauma during coronary catheterization or cardiopulmonary bypass

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman developed a sudden severe headache and vomiting. Her neighbor rushed her to the hospital where she was declared dead on arrival. She lived alone and her family history is unknown. An autopsy revealed a subarachnoid hemorrhage and the following findings in her kidneys. Which of the following is incorrect about this condition?

choices.text: Mutation of PKD-1 is responsible for 85% of cases
PKD-2 mutation has higher risk of end-stage renal disease than PKD-1
The PKD genes code for the polycystin protein
Cysts are formed only in 5% of the tubules of the kidney

questions.solution:
This clinical scenario with a subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) and multiple renal cysts is suggestive of autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). The PKD-1 mutation has a higher risk of end-stage renal disease (ESRD) than PKD-2.

ADPKD is a disorder which is characterized by progressive bilateral formation of renal cysts. It is caused by the following mutations:

  • PKD1 gene on chromosome 16 (85%) - codes for polycystin-1
  • PKD2 gene on chromosome 4 (15%) - codes for polycystin-2

Polycystins are transmembrane proteins that are present on the primary cilia of the tubular cells. The mutated proteins in ADPKD alter the normal functioning and triggers cell growth and cyst formation.

Though cysts are formed only in 5% of the tubules of the kidney, they compress surrounding renal tissue due to their enormous growth. This results in loss of renal function.

Related Pearl: Cystic Diseases of the Kidney

Features  Adult PKD Childhood PKD
Mode of inheritance Autosomal dominant Autosomal recessive
Mutation in genes PKD1, PKD2 PKHD1
Proteins produced Polycystin 1, polycystin 2 Fibrocystin
Chromosomes involved 16p, 4q 6p
Extrarenal manifestations 

Multiple cysts in the liver (most common), pancreas, spleen

Berry aneurysms in the circle of Willis - SAH

Colonic diverticuli

Mitral valve prolapse

 Congenital hepatic fibrosis

Other cystic diseases:

Medullary sponge kidney - 

  • Sporadic in origin
  • Characterized by medullary cysts
  • Associated with hematuria, recurrent renal stones, and normal renal function

Multicystic renal dysplasia - 

  • Characterized by irregular, enlarged, multicystic kidneys
  • Associated with ureteropelvic obstruction, ureteral agenesis, or atresia 
  • Bilateral multicystic renal dysplasia  is associated with renal failure

Simple renal cysts - 

  • Characterized by single or multiple cysts with normal-sized kidney
  • Associated with microscopic hematuria

questions.text: A patient suffering from hyperthyroidism is administered a drug that acts by inhibiting the release of thyroid hormone. Identify the drug.
questions.solution:
Potassium iodide inhibits the release of the thyroid hormone.

Iodides of sodium and potassium and Lugol's iodine act by inhibiting thyroid hormone release. Hence, they are also called thyroid constipating agents. They are the fastest-acting agents.

The beneficial effect of iodides peaks over 10-15 days and gradually disappears. Tolerance is hence an issue with the use of iodides.

Related Pearl: Classification of Anti-Thyroid Drugs

 Drugs inhibiting iodide trapping:

  • Thiocyanates
  • Perchlorates
  • Nitrates

Drugs inhibiting hormone synthesis:

  • Propylthiouracil
  • Methimazole
  • Carbimazole

Drugs inhibiting hormone release:

  • Iodine
  • Sodium iodide
  • Potassium iodide
  • Organic iodide

Drugs inhibiting peripheral conversion:

  • Propylthiouracil
  • Amiodarone
  • Iodinated contrast dyes (Iopanoic acid)
  • Propranolol
  • Glucocorticoids

Drugs that destroy thyroid tissue:

  • Radioactive iodine

questions.text: A junior radiologist performing a fetal doppler follows the direction of the flow of oxygenated blood from the placenta to the fetus to examine the fetal circulatory vessels. The sequence that he would follow is:

choices.text: Umbilical artery → inferior vena cava → ductus venosus → right atrium → left atrium
Umbilical artery → superior vena cava → right atrium → ductus arteriosus → left atrium
Umbilical vein → ductus venosus → inferior vena cava → right atrium → left atrium
Umbilical vein → ductus arteriosus → superior vena cava → right atrium → left atrium

questions.solution:
The sequence of oxygenated blood flow from the placenta to the fetal heart is umbilical vein → ductus venosus → inferior venacava → right atrium → left atrium.

Related Pearl: Concepts of Fetal Circulation

Concept 1:

Oxygenated blood from placenta to the fetus via the left umbilical vein.

Concept 2:

Most of the umbilical venous blood shunts via the ductus venosus to the inferior vena cava and gets mixed with deoxygenated blood from the lower part of the body and liver.

Concept 3:

One-third of blood from the inferior vena cava is directly pumped to the left atrium across the foramen ovale; then to the left ventricle; and ejected from there into the ascending aorta, where it supplies the upper body and the brain.

Concept 4:

A major portion of blood enters the right ventricle, mixes with blood from the superior vena cava, and ejects into the pulmonary trunk.

Concept 5:

Ductus arteriosus bypasses the lungs, and hence, a major portion pumps into the descending aorta to perfuse the lower part of the body and the umbilical arteries carry blood to the placenta for oxygenation.

questions.text: A patient presented with pain and stiffness of the right hip. On examination, apparent shortening of the right lower limb was noted. A synovial aspirate was taken which showed the presence of numerous acid-fast bacilli. Which stage of the disease has the patient presented in?
questions.solution:
The above scenario is suggestive of tuberculosis of the hip. An apparent shortening of the limb is seen in the stage of early arthritis.

Clinical features seen in the four stages of TB hip:

  1. Stage of synovitis presents with apparent lengthening of the limb due to abduction deformity. 
  2. Stage of early arthritis presents with apparent shortening of the limb due to adduction deformity.
  3. Stage of advanced arthritis leads to true shortening of the limb because of the destruction of the articular cartilage of the femur and the acetabulum.
  4. Stage of arthritis with subluxation leads to true shortening of the limb. The destruction of acetabulum leads to dislocation of the femur head. This is also known as wandering acetabulum/ mortar and pestle hip because of the widened acetabulum and diminished size of femur head.

The TB of the hip finally results in fibrous ankylosis of the hip joint.

Note: The apparent length of the lower limb is measured from the umbilicus to the medial malleolus and the true length of the limb is measured from the anterior superior iliac spine to the medial malleolus. The apparent length is increased when there is abduction deformity of the hip and decreased when there is adduction deformity of the hip.

questions.text: You are doing an autopsy on a 35-year-old man who was allegedly under the influence of recreational drugs and fell into a ditch. What is the conclusive evidence of death by drowning in this case?

choices.text: Presence of fluid in the paranasal sinuses
Dilation of right heart and great veins
None of them is a conclusive evidence

questions.solution:
None of the options are considered as conclusive evidence of drowning.

Option A: The presence of fluid in the paranasal sinuses is not a reliable diagnostic sign of drowning.

Option B: Dilation of right heart and great veins is a subjective and non-specific finding.

Option C: At the present time, the diatom test should be used only as an indicative aid and not as legal proof of drowning. Recently, other water organisms have been advocated as tests for drowning, including soft-bodied protozoa and crustaceans.

questions.text: You want to prescribe a bactericidal drug to a patient having an infection. Which of the following drugs will you not choose?
questions.solution:
Tigecycline is not a bactericidal drug. Tigecycline belongs to a new class of glycylcyclines which is a congener of tetracycline . It is a protein synthesis inhibitor and generally considered as a bacteriostatic.

Isoniazid, daptomycin and ciprofloxacin are all bactericidal agents.

questions.text: In a patient presenting with corneal opacity, deficiency of which of the following could be a likely cause?
questions.solution:
Keratan sulfate I is present between the collagen fibrils in the cornea and plays a major role in corneal transparency. Hence, its deficiency can lead to corneal opacity.

Keratan sulfate is made of repeating units of N-acetyl glucosamine and galactose. Two types of keratan sulfate are seen:

  • Keratan sulfate I - in the cornea
  • Keratan sulfate II - in the cartilage

Dermatan sulfate (DS) also plays a role in corneal transparency. However, DS is widely distributed in the body, mainly in the skin.

questions.text: A 28-year-old term primigravida gave birth to a male baby by face to pubis delivery. Which type of pelvis is this mode of delivery commonly seen with?
questions.solution:
Face to pubis delivery is most commonly associated with anthropoid pelvis.

As the anthropoid pelvis is wider posteriorly, the fetal occiput occupies the posterior segment of the pelvis. Thus, the fetus is present in the occipitoposterior position which leads to a high chance of face-to-pubis delivery.

questions.text: A child was brought with urticarial lesions on the forearm. On examination, Darier's sign was positive. The cells responsible for this condition can be stained with all of the following except:
questions.solution:
The above scenario is suggestive of urticaria pigmentosa caused by cutaneous mastocytosis. The Masson-Fontana stain is used to demonstrate melanin in nevus and malignant melanoma.

Darier's sign is seen in urticaria pigmentosa. It refers to the development of urticaria and erythema around the lesions after mild trauma, including scratching or rubbing of the lesion.

Mast cells may be difficult to differentiate from lymphocytes in routine, hematoxylin, and eosin (H&E)–stained sections. Special metachromatic stains (toluidine blue or Giemsa) are used to visualize their granules.

Stains for mast cells:

  • Toluidine blue
  • Giemsa
  • Tryptase
  • Leder stain (Chloracetate esterase)
  • CD 117

The image below shows mast cells stained with toluidine blue.

questions.text: Which of the following does not occur in patients developing pre-eclampsia?

choices.text: Abnormal trophoblastic invasion of uterine vessels
Maladaptive immunological tolerance to fetal antigens
Maladaptation to cardiovascular changes of normal pregnancy
Increased placental perfusion due to inflammation

questions.solution:
Placental perfusion is reduced in patients developing pre-eclampsia.

The development of pre-eclampsia may be explained by:

  • Abnormal trophoblastic invasion of uterine vessels, leading to decreased placental perfusion.
  • Maternal inflammatory response directed against foreign fetal antigens leading to immunological maladaptation.
  • Maternal maladaptation to cardiovascular and inflammatory changes of normal pregnancy.
  • Genetic factors and epigenetic influences.

questions.text: The following image of a FAST scan in a trauma patient suggests:
questions.solution:
The image of FAST in a trauma patient suggests Positive FAST as there is a fluid collection in the abdominal cavity. The thin anechoic area located between the liver(on the left) and the Kidney(on the right) is a collection of fluid visualized in this RUQ Sonogram image. 

 

FAST stands for Focused assessment with sonography for trauma. It is a rapid diagnostic examination to assess patients with potential thoracoabdominal injuries. It is performed within 2­-4 minutes.

Technique:

  • Patient in the supine position
  • 3.5-5.0 MHz convex transducer
  • Following regions are scanned :
    • Subxiphoid: assess for pericardial effusion and left lobe liver injuries
    • Right upper quadrant: assess for right liver injuries, right kidney injury, and Morison pouch
    • Left upper quadrant: assess for splenic injury and left kidney injury
    • Suprapubic region: assess the bladder and pouch of Douglas

An "extended FAST or eFAST" scan may be performed: left and right thoracic views to assess for pneumothorax and haemothorax.

 

Sequentially order of FAST is:- pericardial sac, the Right Upper Quadrant (RUQ), Left Upper Quadrant (LUQ), and pelvis.

4 ‘Ps’ are evaluated in sequence: Pericardial sac → Perihepatic region → Perisplenic region → Pelvis.

 

Note:-

In Pneumoperitoneum, air is collected in the peritoneal cavity which is usually hyperechoic not anechoic and would appear white in the ultrasound image.

questions.text: An  infant presented with delayed eruption of her teeth. An image of her teeth are shown below. She also has history of blisters over the face, hands and feet on exposure to sunlight since the first week of birth. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
An infant with delayed eruption and reddish discoloration of teeth, and blisters over sun-exposed areas suggests a diagnosis of congenital erythropoietic porphyria. 

Congenital erythropoietic porphyria, also is known as Gunther's disease, is an autosomal recessive porphyria. There is uroporphyrinogen III synthase deficiency, leading to uroporphyrin I and coproporphyrin I accumulation in teeth, bone marrow, erythrocyte, plasma urine and feces.

Infants present with port wine urine or pink stained diapers, severe cutaenous hypersensitivity, and reddish-brown teeth known as erythrodontia. When illuminated with UV light, the teeth show reddish fluorescence. It may cause non-immune hydrops in utero or shortly after birth in severe cases. 

Related Pearl: Types of porphyria

Clinically porphyrias can be classified into:

  • Hepatic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in the liver.
  • Erythropoietic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in bone marrow erythroid cells.

Most porphyrias are autosomal dominant except:
  • ALAD enzyme deficiency porphyria

questions.text:
A 40-year-old man presents to the ER with severe abdominal pain. Guarding is present on per abdomen examination. HR is 110bpm and BP is 88/60mmHg. Erect abdominal X-ray is shown below. Which of the following would you proceed with, for managing this case?
  1. USG abdomen
  2. IV fluids
  3. Exploratory laparotomy
  4. Elective surgery
  5. Conservative management
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and erect X-ray abdomen showing gas under the diaphragm (pneumoperitoneum) is suggestive of gastrointestinal perforation. It is managed by initial resuscitation with IV fluids followed by exploratory laparotomy. It is a surgical emergency.

Management includes:

  • Adequate preoperative resuscitation with intravenous fluids followed by correction of electrolyte imbalance, instituting broad-spectrum intravenous antibiotics and
  • Early surgical intervention/laparotomy to address the cause for pneumoperitoneum and stop further contamination of the peritoneal cavity.

questions.text: Hysterosalpingography was done in a young woman with infertility and menstrual abnormalities. Which of the following findings would not point towards a diagnosis of tubercular salpingitis?

choices.text: A wedge shaped defect at the uterine isthmus
Beading and variations in filling defect
Jagged fluffiness of the tubal outline

questions.solution:
A wedge-shaped defect is not suggestive of tubercular salpingitis. It is seen at the uterine isthmus in patients with a history of Cesarean section with a uterine scar.

Hysterosalpingography (HSG) features of genital tuberculosis are:

  • Lead pipe appearance due to rigid nonperistaltic pipe-like tube 
  • Beading and variation in filling defect
  • Calcification of the tube
  • Jagged fluffiness of the tubal outline
  • Tobacco-pouch appearance of hydrosalpinx and pyosalpinx
  • Golf club appearance with slight or moderate dilatation of the ampullary portion of the fallopian tube.
  • Rosette type appearance secondary to multiple small diverticular like outpouching surrounding the ampulla produced by caseous ulceration.

HSG is contraindicated in genital tuberculosis as it causes dissemination of the infection. This further increases the damage to the fallopian tubes. 

The investigation of choice in genital tuberculosis is an endometrial biopsy. The tubercle bacilli are present in the deeper layers of the endometrium. They come to the surface just before menstruation. Hence, an endometrial biopsy is done 1 or 2 days before menstruation.

Menstrual blood can also be used for detecting mycobacteria.

An HSG showing the features of tuberculous salpingitis is given below.

questions.text: A male child with cryptorchidism presents with large dirty brown scales on body flexures. Workup revealed steroid sulfatase deficiency. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
X-linked recessive ichthyosis is a disease affecting only males and presenting with large, generalized dirty brown-black scales encroaching flexures along with cryptorchidism.

It is due to a mutation in the STS gene encoding steroid sulfatase. 

At the age of 2–6 months, usually large thick dark brown to yellow‐brown hyperkeratosis develop covering the trunk, the extremities and the neck. Skin biopsy shows hyperkeratosis with hypergranulosis. Palms, soles, and larger flexures are spared. Deep stromal corneal opacity is a frequent finding.

questions.text: What is the predominant inheritance pattern of sideroblastic anemia?
questions.solution:
Inherited forms of sideroblastic anemia are usually X-linked. Rarely, autosomal recessive forms may also occur.

X-linked sideroblastic anemia results from the deficient activity of the erythroid form of ALA-synthase (ALA-synthase 2) and is associated with ineffective erythropoiesis

questions.text: An infant with hydrocephalus is found to have pancytopenia and hepatosplenomegaly. On further investigations, he is also found to have rugger-jersey spine on X-ray. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of the infantile form of osteopetrosis. It is characterised by decreased osteoclastic activity due to defect in carbonic anhydrase ll proton pump.

The excessive new bone formation with defective resorption leads to abnormal development of the skull, especially causing narrowing of the foramina of the skull. This leads to various complications like hydrocephalus, cranial nerve compression leading to deafness and facial palsy, sinus blockage, etc. 

Failure of bone resorption results in poorly formed medullary cavity. This leads to defective hematopoiesis in the medullary cavity and stimulation of extramedullary hematopoiesis. Hence, the infant presents with pancytopenia and hepatosplenomegaly.

Abnormal bone density may also lead to altered vasculature causing complications like osteitis of the mandible.

Excess bone density also leads to endobone appearance and rugger jersey appearance of vertebrae on radiograph. X-ray spine of a patient with osteopetrosis is given below.

Renal osteodystrophy also shows rugger jersey appearance of vertebrae on x-ray. However, renal osteodystrophy is a complication of chronic kidney disease and the patient is an infant. So the likely answer in the patient in the given scenario is osteopetrosis (Option B).

questions.text: A patient presented with fever and pain abdomen. He had undergone liver transplantation a month ago and is taking immunosuppressants. On examination, abdominal guarding was present and on auscultation, no bowel sounds were heard. Doppler showed hepatic artery thrombosis. Which of the following medications is he most likely on?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of peritonitis due to hepatic artery thrombosis. Sirolimus is known to cause hepatic artery thrombosis in liver transplant recipients.

Sirolimus is an mTOR inhibitor and prevents T cell activation. It is not used commonly in liver transplant recipients because of the increased frequency of hepatic artery thrombosis in the first month posttransplantation. However, they can be used in patients with calcineurin inhibitor-related nephrotoxicity.

questions.text: All of the following supply the marked structure except :
questions.solution:
The structure marked is the right ventricle. It is not supplied by the diagonal artery.

The diagonal artery is a branch of the anterior interventricular artery supplying the left ventricle. This is present in about 30-50% of the population.

The right ventricle is mostly supplied by the right coronary artery and its branches such as the marginal artery.

The anterior interventricular artery gives off 1-2 anterior right ventricular branches.

questions.text: Identify the procedure.
questions.solution:
The procedure depicted in the image represents myelography.

Myelography is a procedure used to evaluate spinal conditions. X-ray myelography can be used to evaluate the spinal canal in patients with spondylolisthesis. While MRI has largely replaced X-ray myelography it is done when there is a contraindication to MRI (Eg; non-compatible pacemaker, severe claustrophobia).

questions.text: Which among the following about idiosyncratic asthma is false?

choices.text: Negative skin test for common inhalant allergens

questions.solution:
Idiosyncratic or intrinsic asthma does not present in childhood. It typically shows a later onset of disease (adult-onset asthma).

Related Pearl: Extrinsic vs Intrinsic asthma

Component Extrinsic asthma Intrinsic asthma
Other names Atopic/ allergic asthma Non-atopic/ non-allergic/ idiosyncratic asthma
Associated with  Atopy, drug or food allergy (past or family history) Samter’s triad (asthma + aspirin sensitivity + sinus disease with recurrent nasal polyps)
Onset Childhood Adult
Inflammation Eosinophil mediated Neutrophil mediated
IgE levels ↑ IgE (type 1 hypersensitivity) Normal IgE (negative skin prick test)
Most common trigger Dermatophagoides (House mite)

Superantigen - 
S. aureus enterotoxin
Response to inhaled corticosteroids Responds well 

Decreased short term response
Prognosis Good Bad

questions.text: A patient came with complaints of inability to move his 4th and 5th digit, cannot hold a pen and he was not able to hold a paper between fingers. Which of the following sites given below is the probable cause of injury to the nerve in question?
questions.solution:
The given clinical situation suggests an ulnar nerve injury. The most likely site of injury would thus be medial epicondyle (marked as C)

Tests for ulnar nerve lesions are as follows:

  • Card test positive
  • Claw hand deformity
  • Froment's sign positive
  • Wartenberg sign
  • Palmaris brevis sign

Positive card test is due to weakness of palmar interrosei, causing loss of adduction. As a result, the patient is unable to hold the card firmly between his or her fingers.

Option A: It is the radial groove where radial nerve runs along with profunda brachii artery.

Option D: It is the neck of humerus where axillary nerve runs around.

Option B: It is the lateral epicondyle. Fracture of this part may lead to tardy ulnar nerve palsy, but incidence is less.

questions.text: Cystoscopy performed on a patient with painless hematuria showed a fungating mass in the bladder. Exposure to all of the following agents can cause this disease except:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of bladder carcinoma. Benzol does not cause bladder cancer, it causes leukemia. 

Bladder carcinoma is associated with exposure to aniline dyes like benzidine, beta-naphthylamines, auramine, magenta, and drugs like cyclophosphamide.

questions.text: A surgeon performs a hysterectomy for uterine fibroids after obtaining relevant informed consent from the patient.  Despite adequate precaution, the ureter was injured intraoperatively. Under which of the following principles will the doctor not be held responsible for this act?
questions.solution:
The doctor will not be responsible for the above act under medical maloccurrence.

Medical Maloccurrence/Inevitable Accident: Every human being responds differently to different drugs as well as to different treatment modalities. On certain occasions, despite all proper care given by the doctor during treatment, the patient fails to respond properly or may suffer some adverse reactions to the drug which may lead to severe injuries or permanent deformities. This is known as a medical maloccurrence/inevitable accident. 

If the doctor can prove this before the court, it will be an absolute defence against malpractice.

'Res ipsa loquitur' means 'the thing or fact speaks for itself'. It is obvious evidence of the negligent act committed. For example, swabs left in the abdominal cavity post laparotomy.

'Novus actus interveniens': This essentially means that the negligence at the core of the lawsuit stems from the actions of a third party and that this negligence was unforeseeable. The viability of this defence heavily relies on the specific details of each case. For instance, if a doctor writes a prescription that is allegedly illegible, and the pharmacist misreads it, fails to verify it with the doctor, and then dispenses the wrong medication to the patient, resulting in an injury, the doctor might use this defence in such a scenario.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man who is known to have end-stage renal disease comes to the OPD for follow-up. He says that he has been having a burning type of pain mainly over the first, second, and third digits. Examination shows the below findings. Which of the following is true about this condition?

choices.text: Can be confirmed by X ray

questions.solution:
The image shows atrophy of thenar eminence as seen in carpal tunnel syndrome. It is due to compression of the median nerve where it passes under the flexor retinaculum in the wrist.

Patients present with pain and paresthesia over the radial 3 and a half digits. There may be weakness of thumb opposition. In chronic cases, the thenar eminence is wasted. Carpal tunnel syndrome can be associated with rheumatoid arthritis, pregnancy, chronic renal failure, acromegaly, hypothyroidism, and gout. The diagnosis is usually made on clinical grounds but nerve conduction studies can confirm the diagnosis.

Tinel's sign is positive in this condition. Sensory symptoms are reproduced by percussing over the median nerve.

Phalen's test is positive where the symptoms are reproduced by holding the wrists in full flexion with the dorsum of the hands pressed together. 

Durkan's test is the most specific test for the diagnosis of carpal tunnel syndrome. In Durkan's test, direct median nerve compression elicits paresthesias and pain.

Related Pearl: Compression neuropathies

Syndrome 

Nerve involved

Pronator teres syndrome

Median nerve (proximally compressed beneath ligament of Struthers, bicipital aponeurosis, or origins of pronator teres)

Radial tunnel (Arcade of Frohse) syndrome

Posterior Interosseous nerve (in proximal forearm)

Cubital tunnel syndrome

Ulnar nerve behind medial epicondyle

Cheiralgia Paresthetica (Wartenburg syndrome)

Superficial sensory branch of radial nerve

Carpal tunnel syndrome

Median nerve (at wrist)

Guyon's canal syndrome

Ulnar nerve(at wrist)

Thoracic outlet syndrome

Lower trunk of brachial plexus

Tarsal tunnel syndrome

Piriformis syndrome

Sciatic nerve
Meralgia paresthetica Lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh
Mortons Metatarsalgia Interdigital plantar nerve

questions.text: What is the correct WHO staging for an HIV-infected child with unexplained persistent parotid enlargement?
questions.solution:
Unexplained persistent parotid enlargement in an HIV-infected child is categorized as stage 2 of HIV disease according to WHO staging.

Related Pearl: Clinical stages of HIV in children/ infants

Stage 1

  • Asymptomatic
  • Persistent generalized lymphadenopathy

Stage 2

General-

  • Unexplained persistent hepatosplenomegaly
  • Recurrent or chronic upper respiratory infections (otitis media, otorrhoea, sinusitis, tonsilitis)
  • Fungal nail infections

Oral-

  • Recurrent oral ulcerations
  • Unexplained persistent parotid enlargement
  • Linear gingival erythema

Skin- 

  • Papular pruritic eruptions
  • Extensive wart virus infection
  • Extensive molluscum contagiosum
  • Herpes zoster

Stage 3

General-

  • Unexplained moderate malnutrition not adequately responding to standard therapy
  • Unexplained persistent diarrhea (14 days or more)
  • Unexplained persistent fever (above 37.6 °C intermittent or constant, for longer than one month)
  • Unexplained anemia (<8 g/dL), neutropenia (<0.5 x 109/L) or chronic thrombocytopenia (<50 × 109/L)

Oral-

  • Persistent oral candidiasis (after first 6-8 weeks of life)
  • Oral hairy leukoplakia
  • Acute necrotizing ulcerative gingivitis/periodontitis

Respiratory-

  • Pulmonary TB/ Lymph node TB
  • Severe recurrent bacterial pneumonia
  • Symptomatic lymphoid interstitial pneumonitis
  • Chronic HIV-associated lung disease including bronchiectasis

Stage 4

General-

  • Unexplained severe wasting, stunting or malnutrition not responding to standard therapy
  • Chronic herpes simplex infection; (oro-labial or cutaneous of more than one month's duration or visceral at any site)
  • Extrapulmonary TB and disseminated non-tuberculosis mycobacterial infection
  • Kaposi sarcoma
  • Oesophageal candidiasis (or candidiasis of trachea, bronchi or lungs)
  • Cytomegalovirus infection; retinitis or CMV infection affecting another organ, with onset at age over 1 month)
  • Disseminated endemic mycosis (extrapulmonary histoplasmosis, coccidioidomycosis)
  • Chronic cryptosporidiosis and isosporiasis
  • Symptomatic HIV-associated nephropathy or HIV-associated cardiomyopathy

Neurological-

  • Central nervous system toxoplasmosis (after one month of life)
  • HIV encephalopathy
  • Cerebral or B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma
  • Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy
  • Extrapulmonary cryptococcosis (including meningitis)

Respiratory-

  • Pneumocystis pneumonia
  • Recurrent severe bacterial infections (e.g., empyema, pyomyositis, bone or joint infection, meningitis, but excluding pneumonia)

questions.text: A patient with chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis was administered transfer factor as treatment. What type of immunity does this result in?
questions.solution:
Adoptive immunity occurs when transfer factor is given.

Transfer factor is composed of an extract of immunologically competent lymphocytes such as T lymphocytes, NK cells, macrophages, or B cells. It has the ability to passively transfer cell-mediated immunity against antigens to which the donor is sensitive.

It has been attempted in the treatment of lepromatous leprosy and chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs approach zero-order kinetics at higher therapeutic levels?
questions.solution:
Phenytoin kinetics changes from first-order to zero-order kinetics at higher therapeutic levels.

True zero-order kinetics is shown only by ethanol. Some drugs have first-order kinetics at low plasma concentrations while at higher plasma concentration (within therapeutic range), the mechanism for elimination gets saturated and they change over to zero-order kinetics.

Drugs that show early saturation kinetics include: 

  • Warfarin
  • Aspirin
  • Theophylline
  • Verapamil
  • Fluoxetine
  • Phenytoin

Some drugs show zero-order kinetics at much higher (non-therapeutic / toxic) levels.

All the other options exhibit first order kinetics. 

Related Pearl: Zero order vs First order kinetics of drugs

Zero order

First order

Constant amount of drug is eliminated per unit time

 Constant fraction of drug is eliminated per unit time

Rate of elimination is independent of plasma concentration

 Rate of elimination is proportional to the plasma concentration

Clearance is more at low concentration and less at high concentration

 Clearance remains constant 

Half-life is less at low concentration and more at high concentration

 Half-life remains constant

Very few drugs follow zero-order kinetics, e.g.(WATT Power)

  • Warfarin
  • Alcohol, Aspirin
  • Tolbutamide
  • Theophylline 
  • Phenytoin

 

 Most of the drugs follow first order kinetics

questions.text: A 35-year-old man with asthma presents with complaints of increased urination. The doctor checks that he has been taking theophylline and counsels that it could be a side effect. What is the mechanism of action causing diuresis?
questions.solution:
The diuretic effect of theophylline is due to the blockade of adenosine (A1) receptors.

Theophylline is a methylxanthine drug that acts by -

  • Inhibition of phosphodiesterase enzyme (PDE) 
    • PDE3 inhibition - relaxation of bronchial smooth muscle 
    • PDE4 inhibition - inhibition cytokines and chemokine release, which leads to a decrease in immune cell migration and activation
  • Blockade of adenosine receptors inhibits bronchoconstriction, however, blockade of A1 receptors in the glomerular afferent arteriole and PCT causes diuresis.
  • Activating enzyme histone deacetylase-2, which is responsible for its anti-inflammatory action

questions.text: A patient presents to your OPD with galactorrhea and amenorrhea. Apart from the determination of serum prolactin levels, which other investigation would you like to do?
questions.solution:
TSH should be measured along with the prolactin level to rule out hypothyroidism which can cause hyperprolactinemia.

Note: However, pregnancy (using qualitative HCG) should be ruled out in all women of the reproductive age group with amenorrhea.

questions.text: The given chest X-ray is suggestive of:
questions.solution:
The given chest X-ray shows a boot-shaped cardiac silhouette which is suggestive of the Tetralogy of Fallot.

The boot-shaped (coeur en sabot) cardiac silhouette is seen due to the right ventricular hypertrophy and upward shift of the cardiac apex. The hilar areas and lung fields appear relatively clear due to reduced pulmonary blood flow or the small size of the pulmonary arteries, or both. 

In Ebsteins's anomaly (Option D) box-shaped heart is seen. 

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in some congenital heart defects

Boot shaped heart - Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF)

 

Egg on string appearance - Transposition of Great Arteries (TGA)

 

Snowman's heart appearance or figure of 8 appearance - Supracardiac TAPVC

 

Box Shaped Heart - Ebstein's Anomaly

questions.text: Which of the following modalities is not used for the treatment of leiomyomas?
questions.solution:
Ultrasound-guided transcervical metroplasty is not used in the treatment of leiomyomas. It is used for the resection of the uterine septum. 

Uterine artery embolization/Uterine fibroid embolization (UAE/UFE) is an angiographic interventional procedure that delivers polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) microspheres or other synthetic particulate emboli into both uterine arteries thus producing ischemia and necrosis. The vessels serving leiomyomas have a larger caliber, hence these microspheres are preferentially directed to the tumors, thus sparing the surrounding myometrium.

Nd:YAG myolysis is laparoscopic myolysis performed with an Nd:YAG laser. It causes coagulation of a subserous fibroid. 

The below image shows uterine artery embolization.

 

Magnetic Resonance guided Focused Ultrasound (MRgFUS) is also called MR-guided high-intensity focused ultrasound (MR-HIFU).

Ultrasound energy is focused to heat and incite coagulative necrosis in selected myomas. Concurrent MR imaging enables precise targeting and provides real-time tissue temperature feedback to limit surrounding thermal injury.

The given image shows MRgFUS.

questions.text: You are the 2nd year Anaesthesia PG on call. You are paged to the COVID ICU. A 50 year old patient who was on non-invasive ventilation is desaturating rapidly. The anaesthetist instructs you to intubate the patient with an endotracheal tube. What is the most commonly used laryngoscopic blade for this procedure?
questions.solution:
The most commonly used laryngoscopic blade for endotracheal intubation in adults is Macintosh.

Laryngoscopic blades can be:

Macintosh - curved laryngoscopic blade. It is preferred for use in adults.

Miller - straight laryngoscopic blade. It is used in 

  • Neonates, infants and young children 
  • Adults with short thyromental distance and long floppy epiglottis.

The advantage of a curved Macintosh blade is that there would be greater room available for the passage for an endotracheal tube and significantly less damage to the teeth.

Macintosh laryngoscopic blade

The curved MacIntosh blade tip is placed in the vallecula after the tongue is slid leftward and anteriorly. The laryngoscope handle is lifted in a forward and upward direction (stretching the hyoepiglottic ligament). This causes the epiglottis to move upward, exposing the arytenoid cartilages and eventually the vocal cords.

questions.text: An infant's mother is distressed that her baby refuses her feeds and starts vomiting immediately when fed and becomes lethargic. After thorough investigations, the baby is diagnosed with HHH syndrome. Which of the following is least likely to be found?
questions.solution:
Hyperuricemia is not a component of HHH syndrome

HHH syndrome is a rare autosomal-recessive disorder caused by a defect in the transport system of ornithine from the cytosol into the mitochondria (deficiency of ornithine permease/translocase), resulting in the accumulation of ornithine in the cytosol leading to hyperornithinemia and a deficiency of this amino acid in mitochondria results in the disruption of the urea cycle and hyperammonemia. Homocitrulline is formed from the reaction of mitochondrial carbamyl phosphate with lysine, which can become a substrate for the OTC reaction when ornithine is deficient.

Components of HHH syndrome:

  • Hyperammonemia
  • Hyperornithinemia
  • Homocitrullinemia

questions.text: The given injury would have most likely occurred due to:
questions.solution:
The image above shows Lichtenberg figures. This type of injury would have most likely occurred due to a lightning strike.

Lichtenberg's figures also called arborescent or filigree burns are superficial, thin, irregular, and tortuous markings over the skin that resemble the branches of a tree. They usually appear within minutes to an hour of a lightning injury and are observed as having a fern-like pattern of erythema over the skin of the shoulders or the flanks. 

They occur due to staining of the tissues by hemoglobin released by lysed red blood cells along the path of the lightning strike. They can also appear due to the rupture of smaller blood vessels in several places giving rise to ecchymoses.

Its recognition may be lifesaving in the unaccompanied comatose patient and is important because even delayed resuscitation of lightning victims can be very successful.

questions.text: In which of the following tissues does gluconeogenesis take place?
questions.solution:
The liver and kidney are the two major locations where gluconeogenesis takes place.

During short periods of fasting, most gluconeogenesis takes place in the liver, while the remaining takes place in the kidneys. However, during periods of prolonged fasting, the kidneys become a major site of gluconeogenesis.

Gluconeogenesis is the process of synthesizing glucose or glycogen from non-carbohydrate precursors. It occurs in cytosol and mitochondria of the liver and kidney. Significant substrates are glucogenic amino acids, lactate, glycerol, and propionate.

Lactate generated in various tissues is transported to the liver and is converted back to pyruvate and enters gluconeogenesis. This pathway is referred to as Cori’s cycle. The Glucose-alanine cycle is referred to as the Cahill cycle.

Muscle cannot participate in gluconeogenesis since it lacks glucose-6-phosphatase.

Related Pearl: Irreversible enzymes in gluconeogenesis pathway

The enzymes can be remembered using the mnemonic Pathway Produces Fresh Glucose.

Enzymes Reaction and site Cofactors
Pyruvate carboxylase

Pyruvate → Oxaloacetate

mitochondria

Biotin, ATP

Activated by acetyl-CoA
Phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase Oxaloacetate → PhosphoenolPyruvate (cytosol) GTP
Fructose-1,6-bisphosphatase Fructose-1,6-bisphosphate → fructose-6-phosphate (cytosol)

Citrate(+ve)

Fructose 2,6 bisphosphate (-ve)
Glucose-6-phosphatase Glucose-6-phosphate → glucose Endoplasmic reticulum  

Related Pearl: Transport of ammonia in blood (Cahill and Cori cycle)

questions.text: A 32-year-old primigravida delivered a full-term male baby by vaginal delivery.  She is a known case of rheumatic mitral stenosis for 4 years. After the delivery of the placenta, she started to bleed profusely.  Which among the following should not be used to control bleeding?
questions.solution:
The given scenario indicates postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) in a primigravida with rheumatic mitral stenosis. Methyl ergometrine is contraindicated in patients with organic heart disease.

Contraindications of methyl ergometrine are:

  • Twin pregnancy - Second baby gets compromised by tetanic contractions of uterus if given after delivery of first baby
  • Organic cardiac disease - Causes overloading of right heart by squeezing blood from uterine circulation.
  • Severe pre-eclampsia and eclampsia
  • Rh negative mother -  Increases chance of fetomaternal transfusion.

questions.text: A hypertensive patient is on metoprolol. If verapamil is added, there is a risk of:
questions.solution:
Metoprolol, when added with verapamil, leads to bradycardia with AV block.

Verapamil and β blockers have additive effect on inhibiting SA node and AV conduction, and the combination should be avoided to prevent severe bradycardia and conduction block.

These agents can also have additive effect on decreasing left ventricular function which could seriously impair cardiac output in a patient with heart failure.

Related Pearl: European society of cardiology guidelines for treatment of hypertension

Indication

Initial treatment of choice 

Hypertension alone or hypertension with diabetes/ cerebrovascular disease

ACEi/ARB + CCB/diuretic (A+C or A+D)

Hypertension with coronary artery disease

ACEi/ ARB + beta blocker/CCB (A+B or A+C)

or

beta-blocker + diuretic (B+D)

or 

CCB+ diuretic/ beta-blocker (C+B or C+D)

Hypertension with chronic kidney disease

ACEi/ARB + CCB/diuretic (A+C or A+D)

Hypertension with heart failure and reduced ejection fraction

ACEI/ ARB + diuretic + beta-blocker (A+D+B)

Pregnancy

Labetalol, Nifedipine, methyldopa

ACEi – Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors

ARB – Angiotensin II receptor blockers

CCB – Calcium Channel Blockers

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding ovarian cysts?

choices.text: Cobweb appearance is seen on USG in haemorrhagic cyst
Theca lutein cyst regresses with a fall in hCG levels
Leutoma of pregnancy is associated with multiple pregnancy
Follicular cyst is a benign epithelial tumor

questions.solution:
Follicular cyst is a physiological/functional cyst of the ovary. 

Physiological/functional cysts of the ovary:

  1. Follicular cyst - Failure of rupture of the follicle during ovulation.
  2. Theca lutein cyst - Stimulation of atretic follicles by abnormal HCG levels. It regresses when hCG levels fall.
  3. Luteoma of pregnancy - Due to prolonged elevation of hCG, like in multiple pregnancies.

Hemorrhagic ovarian cysts usually occur due to bleeding into the corpus luteum or other functional cysts at the time of ovulation. Hemorrhagic cysts are normal findings in ovulatory women, generally resolving within 8 weeks. 

Cobweb appearance on USG in a hemorrhagic cyst is shown below.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man who is a laborer presents with progressive weakness of the legs. He says that the weakness is more in the morning and as the day progresses, it improves for a while usually. He is a known smoker. Examination reveals diminished deep tendon reflexes in the lower limbs. Which of the following statements is true regarding this condition?

choices.text: Paraneoplastic syndrome seen in lung adenocarcinoma
Incremental response on repetitive nerve stimulation

questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS). Incremental response to repetitive nerve stimulation is a feature of this condition.

LEMS is a neuromuscular junction disorder associated with the reduced acetylcholine (Ach) release from the presynaptic nerve terminals, despite normal ACh vesicle numbers.

Antibodies directed against the P/Q voltage-gated calcium channel (VGCC) interfere with the normal calcium flux required for the release of acetylcholine.

Approximately 50% of LEMS cases are associated with malignancy, mainly small cell lung cancer (SCLC). 

Most patients with LEMS present with symptoms as slowly progressive proximal muscle weakness. In LEMS, the weakness improves for a while after exertion. Diminished or absent deep tendon reflexes help differentiate between LEMS and myasthenia gravis.

An increase in the compound muscle action potential (CAMP) amplitude >100% after exercise or with high-frequency repetitive nerve stimulation (RNS) is considered to be of diagnostic significance.

questions.text: A 68-year-old post-COVID-19 patient presented with a black, foul-smelling nasal discharge and blurred vision. On examination, a blackish necrotic mass eroding the septum and hard palate was visualised. Lactophenol cotton blue mount from the culture is given below. Which of the following statements is false regarding the condition?

choices.text: Iron administration to patients with active infection should be avoided
Posaconazole can be used to treat it
Pulmonary form is the most common

questions.solution:
Black, foul-smelling nasal discharge, blurred vision, blackish necrotic mass over the septum and palate, and the Lactophenol cotton blue (LPCB) mount showing aseptate hyphae branching at right-angles are strongly suggestive of mucormycosis. Rhino-orbito-cerebral mucormycosis is the most common form of mucormycosis. Pulmonary mucormycosis is the second most common form.

Mucormycosis is an invasive disease caused principally by species of Rhizopus, Mucor, and Lichtheimia. The disease is often characterized by hyphae growing in and around the blood vessels. Rhino-orbital- cerebral disease is the most common form of mucormycosis. Patients initially present with eye or facial pain, facial numbness, conjunctival suffusion and swelling, and blurry vision. Infection then spreads from the ethmoid sinus to the orbit, leading to proptosis and orbital cellulitis. The sinus tissue in such patients often develops into a black necrotic eschar. 

Rhizopus is angioinvasive, and thus the infection may spread to the frontal lobe and cavernous sinus, leading to septicemia and thromboses. This can be fatal. 

Risk factors for the infection include:

  • Diabetes (Diabetic ketoacidosis).
  • Elevated levels of free iron.
  • Defects in phagocytic function.
  • Organ or hematopoietic stem transplantation.

Treatment of choice is Amphotericin-B. Posaconazole can be used as an alternative drug.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a type of subcortical dementia?
questions.solution:
Pick's disease (a type of frontotemporal dementia) is a type of cortical dementia.

Examples

Related Pearl: Differential diagnosis of dementia

Condition Features
Alzheimer’s disease
  • Insidious onset
  • Short-term memory loss
  • Language deficits and spatial disorientation
  • Later, personality changes
Vascular Dementia

  • Early executive dysfunction
  • Cerebral infarction &/or deep white matter changes on neuroimaging

(Pick’s disease)

  • Urinary Incontinence

  • Dilated ventricles on neuroimaging

(Prion disease)

  • Rapidly progressive
  • Myoclonus and/or seizures

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman at 35 weeks of gestation is wheeled into the labour room following the onset of labor. A forceps delivery is planned for her. Which of the following is not a contraindication for this?
questions.solution:
Forceps can be used to deliver a preterm baby where it is believed to form a protective cage. Vacuum is contraindicated in these cases.

Contraindications of forceps delivery:

  • Unengaged head
  • Cephalopelvic disproportion 
  • Malpresentations like brow and face (mentoposterior position)
  • Cervix not completely dilated
  • Inability to define position
  • Fetal coagulopathy or osteogenesis imperfecta

Note: Forceps delivery is only reserved for mentoanterior position.

Related Pearl: Obstetrics forceps

Commonly used forceps: 

1) Simpson forceps

  • The most commonly used types of forceps in outlet delivery.
  • Has elongated cephalic curve.
  • These are used when there is substantial molding of the fetal head.

2) Elliot forceps

  • Has an adjustable pin for regulating the lateral pressure on the handles.
  • They are used most often when there is minimal molding.
  • More suitable for outlet delivery.

3) Kielland forceps

  • Has small pelvic curve and a sliding lock.
  • Suitable for head with little molding.
  • The most common forceps used for rotational delivery.
  • Helps correct asynclitism.

4) Piper forceps

  • Distinct perineal curve.
  • Allows for application to the after-coming head in breech delivery.

5) Tucker-McLane forceps

  • Suitable for fetal head with little molding.
  • Used in rotational delivery.

6) Barton forceps and traction handle

  • Used in rotational delivery.
  • Most importantly used for delivery of occipitotransverse positions in a platypelloid pelvis.
  • It is an obsolete procedure.

questions.text: Which of the following oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curves corresponds to blood from an adult (dark blue line) and blood from a fetus (light blue line)?
questions.solution:
Curve C corresponds to blood from an adult (dark blue line) and blood from a fetus (light blue line). The fetal oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve is shifted to the left relative to the adult curve.

The fetal hemoglobin (Hb F) has a greater affinity for O2 than adult hemoglobin (Hb A). This facilitates the movement of O2 from the mother to fetus. The cause of this greater affinity is the poor binding of 2,3-DPG by ɣ polypeptide chains that replace β chains in Hb F. The fetal oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve is thus shifted to the left relative to the adult curve. Typically, fetal arterial Po2 is low, hence leftward shift enhances placental uptake of O2.

questions.text: Which of the following culture media is used to differentiate other E.coli species from E.coli O157: H7?
questions.solution:
E.coli O157: H7 can be differentiated from other E.coli species using sorbitol MacConkey agar. 

There are more than 150 serotypes of Shiga toxin-producing E.Coli (STEC). Of these, O157:H7 is the most common type. Unlike most other E.Coli serotypes, the STEC O157:H7 does not use sorbitol and produces clear colonies on the Sorbitol MacConkey agar.

O157: H7 strains also are negative for β-glucuronidase using the substrate 4-methylumbelliferyl-β-glucuronide (MUG) test. More than 90 per cent of other E.coli tests positive with this substrate.
